reviews.review: A national treasure. As with any major city you will see fine works of art in the museum of fine arts. Of particular interest are the world renown Argentinian artists. The frames on their paintings are of equal beauty. A definite must see. Be careful not to cross the marked lines in front of the paintings as you will be reminded by the guards...

Excellent presentation of Argentinean art. Free admission to 2 floors of well laid out art. The pieces progressed from room to room in a temporal fashion which was interesting to me. Some surprising European masters. Just enough to maintain the interest and not be overwhelmed by volume.

Small but charming exhibits. If you're walking down around the Recoleta area and you have a few moments to spare, check out this free (a word you'll hear often in Buenos Aires) gallery with some interesting art. It lacks information in other languages, but it should be fine. Great for a quick visit and a place to sit down for a while.
Magical place. I spent there half day with my family and it was very interesting to see arts from such famous artists!
Free entrance!. Great museum with some interesting paintings. The entrance is free so if you are in the area I would recommend you visiting this museum.

Very surprising. Rodin's KISS was my first surprise, then an amazing series of Impressionists paintings I equally did not expect to see, non behind glass either!Beyond these gems there was yet more excellent exhibits, Chinese pottery, fans, and exclusive object da donated by a mystery lacy, boy she must have been wealthy in the 1920,'sWell worth a visit and it's free!

Good art museum. The Bellas Artes is a very good art museum. It has many painting from the masters as well as contemporary artists. There are quite a few marble statues and bronze works and interesting modern abstract works. You need at least a couple of hours to go through the many galleries.
Excellent selection of Fine Art.. Wow! And, Wednesdays are free. This museum has the best fine art in Buenos Aires. Easy access close to Recoleta.
One of the best museums in BA. Wide variety of paintings from different eras. Easy to visit in a single afternoon. Located in one of the nicest areas of Recoleta in BA-

an inteligent way to spent some 3 hours among real pieces of art. in a good vicinity with easy access , we have spent 3 hours it looks like an old european fine art gallery with nicw colourful paintings

A real surprise. I loved this place, it had a great selection of artwork and was a lovely space to wander around. As good as any art museum I have been to in Europe. I spent a few hours there. Just across from the Recoleta Market and Cemetery and totally free.

An absolute gem!. We were absolutely amazed at the collection of art in this Gallery. It is one of the best we have visited and certainly not to be missed if you are in Buenos Aires. Great South America art collection and other international artists too. (Free entry)

very good museum, well presented art, and allow pics without flash!. it is getting rare that a fine art museum allows pics without flash- this one still allow pics w/o flash! great art pieces, well presented with good ligting. You are allowed to get qie close to the paintings, which is nice to see the details...and.. it is FREE!

Wonderful gem. This is a fantastic museum with a wide range of stunning artwork both international and local, with an added bonus is it is free to enter :) Definitely worth a visit.
It is just a short walk away from Recoleta Cemetery.

Art for all !. These collection has a nice tradicional history, based in the wealh of two local families whom decided to donate it to the argentinian people ! FREE entrance to tree very large floors full of magnificent art, from medieval to contemporane all tastes shall be pleased ! Well worth a visit specially if the weather isn't the best here you can expend at least tree to four hours. A pittty that there isnot a coffee lor resto !!

get lost a bit. had no intentions of coming here but I was draged anyway. To my surprise it was overwelmingly cool even with my lack of art knowledge. you do not have to be a pro to appreciate a place like this.
Simply lovely. Well maintained and has a variety of that would satisfy people with very different tastes in art. It shows the uniqueness of many Argentinian artists.

Wonderful.. I visited twice during a 2-week vacation. If you go on Sunday afternoon, walk through the crafts fair in Plaza Francia, which is the park adjacent to Recoleta Cemetery, then right across the street to this large, coral-colored museum.After going up the stairs or ramp and entering the museum, immediately turn right and enter the galleries with priceless paintings and statues.The museum of free, but consult the Internet for hours. Their gift shop is closed on Sundays. I would go back to Buenos Aires just to wander around the first floor again!Two amusing things: A male guard slept in a chair next to the Zubaran painting. A different guard sat playing with his phone all the time! Security anyone?

Definitely worth a visit!. I spent a rainy afternoon at the museum, and was really impressed by the collection. I was lucky to join an English Tour of the permanent collection (1pm on a Tuesday, not sure if it's daily) which gave a good introduction to Argentinian art. Admission and the tour were free but I would've gladly paid to visit.

Free and Expansive. After google searching for "museums with french paintings in Buenos Aires," I came across this museum and I knew that I had to check it out. I went with my husband and his family after we walked around the Recoleta cemetery. Entry into the museum is free, which is always a great thing. The first floor housed paintings, sculptures, and decorative pieces from multiple centuries. A whole room was devoted to French Impressionists. They even had a private collection which had even more French impressionist paintings! We also enjoyed seeing art from Argentinian artists, as well as a special exhibit with optical illusions. All in all, I would highly recommend visiting this museum if you are in Buenos Aires!

Not an art person, but loved it. There's something for everyone here. A very nice museum which has a large variety of beautiful work. Fantastic for a rainy day, free entry and we spent about 2 hours admiring art. Don't miss this museum, put it above all the others if you're limited for time.

Fine Artw Musuem of Buenos Aires. Stop by and visit th art here. Varied and interesting art. Also artists from argntina and Brazil that I have never heard of . Lighting could be improve to vieFerry from buenos aires to colonia uruguay better and signage in English would b a nice touch. But worth th time to stop in and look around.

This museum houses my favorite Rodin sculpture!. Can't beat the free admission and the ability to see "The Kiss" and original works by Monet and El Greco. There isn't a huge collection of art here, but there's a lot of variety and it's a very pleasant way to spend a few hours.
Great for a rainy afternoon in BA. This museum has a great modern art section featuring many Argentinian artists. It also has a good collection of European artists from the 1600 through the 1900s.

Impressive collection with free admission. While it wasn't an overwhelming collection, I was impressed with the quality and variety. A delightful way to spend an afternoon. Was equally impressed with the free admission. Definitely would return.

Broad collection of beautiful art. The Museo Nacional de Belles Artes was the last museum I visited on my trip and made a fitting end to my vacation. The museum houses artwork--mostly paintings with some sculpture--from the 14th century onward. The collection is arranged in a temporal pattern and by simply walking from room to room one is walking through time, able to see the changes in patterns and fashions of painting. As the collection enters the 19th and 20th century, there's a growing representation of art from Argentinian artists, which makes and interesting contrast to the artists I've been more familiar with (as a US citizen, much of the art I've been exposed to has been of European or US origin). Some highlights for me include a number of fascinating pieces by Rodin, some good examples of Impressionism, and several of the more modern pieces that reflect the tension between figurative and abstract art that played out in the 20th century. Also, the museum is free!
Great Little Museum. A lovely Museum with a few jewels from the masters, including French impresionists. Free. Much worth a visit.

Buenos Aires Gem. National Museum of Fine Arts considered to have the largest public art collection in Latin America with art by Goya, Van Gogh, Gauguin, Manet, Dega and Rodin sculptures and Argentinean artists such as Della Valle and de la Carcova. Enjoyed perusing the collection on a Sunday afternoon while surrounded by Argentines who also took pleasure in the art of the museum as well.
Free museum with old and new art. Contrary to all other museums, this one is free and has a wide range of art collections. They have activities for kids to draw on their own mimicking any collection.

Tour was in Spanish an. Since I do not speak Spanish, the tour was very boring for me. However, my mother-in-law loved it and so did a friend of ours who lives in Recoletta. I would not want to take the tour again but I know that if you love ballet theatre, you will love the history of this one.

Very eclectic and nice . Even if this museum was not free, it is certainly worth a visit. Varied collection of Argentinian art, Dutch masters, world reknown artists and very interesting installations. We enjoyed it very much.
Make Time. We had our hearts set on the Mexican Exhibit but missed it by a couple of days (our fault, to much to do in BA). BUT the rest of the exhibits were well worth the stop.

Art lovers won't be disappointed. First off for a free museum it's fantastic. Plus there was a Berni expo going on while we went in August 2016 which was excellent. There was a lot of art! Personally I enjoyed it more that the Malba. But if you go and find one painting that you like, then its worth it!
Better than we imagined. We enjoyed the museum but thought there was too many European works of art and not Argentinian. It was free so I can't complain. It kept our boys interested for 30 mins!!

Nice collection. It's completely free, which I can't comprehend. They should charge at least a minimal fee. Having said that it's a nice collection with many classic, impressionist and modern artist. I didn't particularly like that the walls are painted in different colors. I prefer white walls for museums, but after the initial shock I didn't notice anymore.Is not a huge museum so is very easy to walk around and enjoy it. Also to my surprise they are ok with taking pictures as long as you don't use a flash. I didn't take any because I am used to a no picture policy.
Free amazing museum. Important pieces of art can be found at the Museo de Bellas Artes. A must if you are in the area. No entrance fee!

Truly splendid, world class with lots of surprises. Well laid out, with truly inspiring unique artwork, reflecting the storied history of Argentina through the beautiful art that was produced as well as brought here. Inspiring and horizon expanding.

Go to special exhibits and second floor. First floor is standard okay big city Bellas Artes museum. Would have said eh, but then hit an incredible exhibit on the Mexican muralists and their relationship to S. America (only here another week). Then went to eye opening exhibit of 20th C Argentine art - impressive. So do first floor quickly - some nice Goyas. But head upstairs before you get museum foot.
Good 45 Minutes on Rainy or First Day. Easy walk from Recoleta Cemetery which makes for a nice arrival day schedule. Do the museum second. 7 out of 10 content.

Excellent museum !. A must-see in B.A.! This museum is not enormous, yet the diversity and quality of the art work is outstanding.... and as other art museums in Buenos Aires, the lovely way they are exhibited adds to the experience. Please be aware, however, that there is very little English related to the exhibits.... also there is no restaurant in the museum-however there's a lovely restaurant around the corner called "900".

Stunning collection. We were blown away with the extensive collections of European masters - this is a beautiful Museum and a 'must see' if you're in the city - we spent several hours here, and luckily its open in the evenings because we stayed until closing! The locals are extremely fortunate to have this magnificent collection on their doorstep.
Art museum Buenos Airies. An excellent gallery to visit with a number of good impressionist paintings and European masters together with local artists, Rodin sculptures and modern art.

Pretty good for its size. It was free to enter and go around few rooms with some stunning art. Only wish is to see it a bit expended and larger. It is a bit weird that such a great city does not allocate better building for the art (and there are many great buildings in this city)
So much fantastic art!. I went here on three different occasions and still didn't see all that the museum has to offer! It's a wonderful collection spanning numerous periods and styles.

Favorite Museum in the City. I could not have planned for a more serendipitous rainy day activity. I'm a huge art nerd, so it felt like home for me. It was one of the best collections of impressionist and romantic works that I've come across since returning from Europe, and outside of the main gallery, there's one room specifically dedicated to Goya. While the museum focuses a good deal on European work, they're currently housing an exhibition on the political framework of Latin America (the works of Rivera, Sisquiero, and Orozco). Not only is it free, but I personally found it more alluring than MALBA. You could spend all day inside and not feel like you saw everything.

It is free and close to evitas cemetery. It is free and has nice art work, not as good as european museums of course. You need to pay 10 peso to mind your bags at reception. It is eady to find being a pinkish red building very near to evitas cemetery

World Class Art Collection in Recoleta. I visited the Museo Nacional de Bellas Artes last week. We walked along Av. del Libertador, a lovely avenue. I am a volunteer at the Getty Center and was very impressed with the Bellas Artes collection. Very important works by Manet, Courbet, Rubens and Rembrandt; many sculptures by Rodin. I enjoyed the beautiful works in the temporary exhibits of Orozco, Rivera and Siqueiros that enhanced my first visit to Buenos Aires. This was a special highlight of my weeklong trip.

An beautiful collection in a beautiful neighborhood. This museum has a really nice collection of both European and South American art. The museum is well kept and well organized, and is THE place to go if you're interested in seeing fine art from Argentina. Admission is free, and the museum is conveniently located in Recoleta neighborhood and is situated in between a series of parks that runs the length of Avenida Libertador. This is the perfect place to spend some time on a rainy day or escape the heat after visiting the nearby Recoleta Cemetery.

Some fine art exhibeted here. Well worth a visit. This museum exhibits some fine art. Paintings and sculptures. Many famous Rodin sculptures can be found here. Entrance is free and the museum is well kept and a pleasure to visit.

Beautiful museum !. I decided to walk from my hotel, it was, after all, a beautiful sunny early winter day in Buenos Aires. I walked, and I walked and I walked some more, mostly in circles and always the wrong way, it seemed. I almost gave up but happened to stumble upon a tourist information booth where I was told I was almost there, just about three blocks away. Once I arrived to the museum I forgot all about my tired feet and enjoyed the rest of the afternoon immensely. And the admission was free !! What a fabulous place to spend a day. I am glad I went and would warmly recommend this place.

Best museum in BA. We went to quite a few museums during our visit in Buenos Aires, including Malba and this was the best one. A quite large collection of great south-american and european art and it's free!
The lighting wasn't great though, some paintings were too dark and some were hard to see because the spotlights made them shine.

Best museum. A spectacular museum! It is impeccable in every way - very well taken care of, staff is very careful wirh the safety of the paintings and statues, there is a large collection of expositions and the guided tour is great. There is a portuguese-speaking guide who took us on a quick journey through the early years of Argentina.

Great museum. I was blown away by the collection - so many beautiful pieces on display and amazing artists featured. The museum is a bit too dim for me, but nevertheless, I loved walking around and soaking everything in. There were a lot of students and some loud groups that were bothersome, but you could choose to walk away from them and enjoy a different part of the museum and come back later. All in all, I really enjoyed the museum. And a great plus is that the museum is free! PS - It took me about 2 hours to go through the whole museum - it is a fairly large collection.

Fabulous Art Collection. What a Gem. Incredible art in a great location. I was incredibly surprised by the collection. Renoir, Degas, Monet...the list goes on. It's a short walk from Recoleta Cemetery. And a weekend market across the road. A must do in BA.

Great collection of Latin American art. This museum has a great collection across various periods. Stunning collections and can be seen in 90 minutes, the staff is pretty friendly. Take an English tour if it's available - the guides are great and add that little extra to your tour

Muralistas Mexicanos. The museum has a lot of the same stuff throughout it. But, they had an exhibition when i went, it was a Mexican Muralists exhibition and it was amazing!!!! FREE everyday (Closed on Mondays)

What a treasure!!. This was not on our radar to visit and so glad we did. Great retrospective of art from Impressionism (stunning collection) to modern day Latin art. Photography is allowed, no flash. Wandering through at a brisk pace, we were there over an hour. Make sure you have covered all the levels, it is a bit quirky.

Free collection. We stumbled upon the museum on a walk. Monet, Manet, Cezan, and many others featured. We were surprised to find the whole thing was free. The place was quite empty (on a Thursday afternoon.)Friendly staff. Famous sculptures in a nearby park
Wonderful museum, worth visiting whenever coming to Bs.As.. I enjoy seeing Argentinian paintings, and depending on what is the being shown on a temporary basis, it's a museum to visit over and over.

Quite small, but free!. I have been a bit spoiled visiting the best museums all over the world. This was a nice collection for a small museum. I was hoping for more impressionists - my favorites. Still, they had a nice temporary exhibition of three big Mexican artists: Rivera, Orozco, and Siqueiros.
If you like impressionists.... Then this is your museum in BA. Degas, Renior, Monet, van Goh to name a few. Also incredible statues by Rodin. It has an incredible collection of art and is free

One of the best Fine Arts Museums of Latin-America. Amazing in this Museusem you can find pieces very old and the vanguard artists. There are a lot of paintings by the most famous painters of the history of art. Sculptures by Rodin and many more. A great Argentine paintings collection. Very ineresting are the tours with guides in different lenguages. I recommend emphatically.

A complete collection that can be seen in 1,5 hours.. This free entrance museum is awesome. Has many Rodin (including the famous kiss), many Degas, Manet, Monet. Has 1 Van Gogh, Picasso. And many latinamerican painters
But also has contemporary art and modern and kinetic art .

Great collection of Renaissance art plus modern art and temporary exhibitions. This museum has recently been renovated and has a great collection of Renaissance art, El Greco, Rodin plus Degas, Renoir and Argentinean artists. The current exhibition of Mexican artists is excellent. The second and third floors have a good collection of modern art and there is a terrace with sculptures. And it's all free!

Pretty good. We took the 1pm English tour sponsored by the museum and open to the public. The tour had a total of about 12 visitors and the guide was well informed and animated. While the tour did move slowly spending quite a bit of time at each piece of art, he did a fine job discussing select pieces of argentine art in the gallery and gave us a strong sense of the factors influencing argentine art over the years. Good option for a rainy day. The important European pieces in the gallery are few. There is an interesting room of modern art. The museum building is lovely and well maintained. No cafe or snack bar.

Great collection!. A very very very small version of the Louvre! This museum in Buenos Aires had a bit of everything - from Baroque to Impressionism - you could catch a small glimpse of various artistic periods.If you know little of argentinian (or south american) art, it's a good place to get to know a little more!As I said, there aren't numerous artworks - but the entrance is free of charge and it's great for a visit at the end of the day.

Art of the forties. Some beautiful art with some thought provoking art pieces, a great exibit on the brazilian natives and the work involved in trying to protect them from disease, it appears cruel with numbered discs placed around their necks, but this was used to identify those immunized. Something that is hard to explain,

Nice Museum. Had a decent collection of European Art. The Latin America collections were interesting. I was surprised by a number of the artists. Can do it in a couple of hours if you want a quick visit.

Under rated. A very good museum, together with the MALBA (Museo de arte Latina en Buenos Aires)of great interest. Entry is free. There are good paintings by notable painters and is easily reachable. Visit both if you can, become a Friend if your stay is prolonged or if you live here. It is well worth it!
Best art museum of Buenos Aires . This is a must go place if you love art, you can take pictures without flash and is free to enter. The fastest way to get there is by bus.
Fabulous Free visit . Yes you saw that right. It's free !!! Beautiful art from local and French masters. Beautiful structure and lovely exhibits. A must to visit

International Art collection.. Not the largest museum, but high quality, impressive collection. And it's free! You can visit the museum in an hour. Great thing to do while you wait for 8 pm for the restaurants to open.
not to miss. very rich museum, you don't have ti miss it. full of nice paintings from all over the world and with air conditioning system

How good. Went here not expecting too much but was blown away by the quality art of the best artists in the world.did not expect to see rooms full of Goya's,Degas,Monet ,Rubens Picasso and all the who's who of art.The entry price-Free!,and cameras allowed.We will visit again

It's Free, It's Great... Just Go! :-). It's got a Van Gogh you've probably never seen, lot's of fantastic paintings and sculpture by international and Argentine greats. You can enjoy it for 5 minutes or 2 hours and there's no pressure to get your "money's worth" because it's free.

Nice Art Gallery. We spent some time in the gallery looking at the various artworks on display. It is a nice gallery with lots of interesting paintings. Nothing in English writing that we could find. Still the paintings are nice. Hard to figure out the theme of any room (if there is one) but the quality of the works on display is high. Enjoyable couple of hours if you are an art lover. Free entry is nice as well.
Great art for free!. The museum is beautiful and has fantastic artwork. Just check the hours before you go though, because they are a little strange and vary by day!
Very nice museum. It is a big museum of art in Buenos Aires. Worth to visit. When I was in B.A, the museum was hosting some Caravaggio´s painting. It was very good to see Caravaggio outside Italy.
Not the best - But interested enough. I wasn't impressed with the museum but again it has a few paintings from famous artists. It is free and can go at any time.
You can't compare this museum with European or American. There are a lot of works of Argentine authors and some of foreign ones but if you are European, I think that you lost your time visiting it.-
boring. boring. they have like one painting of each famous painter from different times and really it's not even the most interesting or representative of the artist.

Good For A Rainy Day. It feels like this museum has one of everything - one Rembrandt, one Degas, one Picasso, etc. So you won't get bored because of the variety. It's free and is good for a visit if it's raining or in the evening (check times). We walked around the area at night and it felt very safe.
Great Selection of Contemporary Art. The gallery collection underlines just how European a city is Buenos Aires - many of the old favourites are here from the 20th Century European canon

go later in the day. an imposing building, with Lautrec, picasso, Rodin and much much more.
free entry, which is always nice.
from the roof you can see the Floralis Generica, which should be visited as the sun sets.

American Gift of Artwork in Ricoleta. Free to the public, this art museum is a surprising collection of priceless works by world renown artists. Highly impressive pieces by Rodin, paintings by Rodin, Manet and Degas are but a sweet taste of the gallery's collection.
Perfect!. Loved it all! Beautiful display of famous art. Enjoyed the Picasso, Monet, and Rembrandt. Staff was informative even with out language barrier.

Nice Collection! Also - Free!!!. I literally stumbled upon this museum with no plans to visit but I am happy that I did! The museum is big with a collection from several countries and several eras. Make sure to follow the galleries sequentially so that you can see the art progression from one generation to the next.

Rainy Day Attraction. My wife and I visited this free attraction whilst in the capital. It killed some time but wasn't 'that exciting'.
It was cultural and we saw what Argentines see as Art, but we weren't blown away by anything that we saw.
Would be alright for something to do on a rainy day.

comprehensive collections. The museum has comprehensive collections of European, South American and Argentinian art. It is certainly worth a 2-3 hours visit. Free entry. No souvenir / bookshop. Very little explanation in other language than Spanish.

Stellar collection . Brilliant range of countries, genres, periods. Far more than you can fully take in in one visit but luckily it's free so you can make return visits.
Small book shop, no café but plenty nearby.
Strangely, not many toilets!

Some nice treasures here. It is a nice surprise to find some nice old masters here. Goya, el Greko, Rembrant, Tiepolo, Rubens and some newbies including, Gaughain, van Goug, Kandinsky, Manet, Modigliani, Pollock etc. not too crowded and easy to get around. Quite nice collections of Argentinean art to compliment. A nice afternoon out.
Interesting. Not bad for those who loves art. The drawings are very lovely and interesting. We had spend over an hour there.

Nice museum centrally located. Altho centrally located, be sure to check the open hours and days. I think it did not open until 1 and I found a bunch of people waiting for it to open. I got to the English Highlight tour at 1:30. It was a large group of us and his English was very good. But disappointed in tour. Most all of the time was spent on histlorical local artists I did not know. I wandered away and found some masters I was familiar with..

Great stop. The museum has some really interesting pieces, and it was free entry to boot. The signage is, unsurprisingly, all in Spanish, but it just meant we had to focus on the works themselves instead of spending our time reading about them. We were really glad we stopped in.

Excellent Art Museum . This is well worth a visit. It holds an excellent and eclectic collection of Western and Latin American works. You'll find many of the European great artists including Monet, Degas (almost a whole small room of his paintings), Van Gogh, Renoir, Gaugin, Chagall, Pissaro, Corot, and Rodin. There are many outstanding and imaginative works by Latin artists that illustrate periods and styles. And the museum has numerous modern paintings and sculpture. Be aware that most of the descriptions are in Spanish.

Some great works. Lovely museum with some works by renowned artists such as Monet, Rembrandt and Van Gogh. There is also a large number of works by local artists. While it is understandable that most visitors would be Spanish, it may also be beneficial to have some text in English as this would probably be the next most understood language by visitors.
A nice compact museum. This is a great plac e to visit on a rainy day, it is important to check opening times, as sometimes they do not open till quite late in the morning
Fantastic!. We were fascinated by all Latin American art. I loved the fact that you have the access to all this artistic stuff to see here in Latin America. Great!

Amazing collection. This museum has a wonderful collection of paintings so definitely worth a visit. Free entry. Works of art by El Greco, Monet, Renoir, Degas, Manet, Pissaro, Goya, etc. Also we were very pleased to see 3 works by the Valencian artist Joaquín Sorolla. Great so see such high quality art in Buenos Aires. Recommended.

Degas. Very interesting museum with many fine artists (Dali, Degas, and yes...even Taloose Latrec). It is well laid out.....please remember to check hours of operation. It didn't open until 1230 on the day we visited. If you arrive early...trek over to the Recoleta Cemetary for a stroll through the amazing mausoleum-city.

Huge Traditional Art Museum. Old masters and more, sort of like the Metropolitan Museum in New York with many works from famed masters of classical periods which we had never before seen. Huge place allow enough time or come back later.

Various art. Museo de Bellas Artes is in a nice building. It hosts many different kind of art of well known persons (eg van Gogh). Unfortunatly there was only printed leaflets in spanish and not much of explanation inside.

Nice and free. I went to MNBA on a Sunday which resulted in tons of people. Both tourists and locals enjoying the free museum. It's got a nice and mixed collection of art. I would especially recommend it because it's free so you won't necessarily feel obligated to walk through all rooms. Try to get there during the week so the crowds might be fewer. The building it self is worth a photo too.

Really good collection of World art. This is a real gem of a museum with a mixed collection of top class European and Argentinian paintings. Use the museum wifi and click on the QR reader images near each picture to get more information. It is in Spanish but if you are online you can translate it. It is a mine of good information without the nee for a guide book.

Amazing collection. Amazing collection for free! You need to dedicate a lot of time. Beside the well known (to me) european artists you will find amazing works of Latin American Artists that you will come to love. Like Antonio Berni!

Valuable collection and surprising stories. No much people expect this quality and quantity of fine art in Buenos Aires, probably. But the collection of great famous arrists like Manet, Monet, Sisley among others surprise everybody. I come back every now and then because they have such a huge collection and not always all the paintings are visible so they change it and you don't know when it happens. The sculptures from Rodin are so beautiful and well shown. The infratructure, the building and lighting is not the best like in the MOMA for instance but still is impressive. Deserves a quick tour with a local guide if you have 1:30 hours and hear the story behind of some paintings.

An important destination.. An important destination who those who enjoy art. There was a surprisingly good collection of contemporary Latin American work in addition to the classic European art the museum is noted for. Highly recommend.
Well worth doing. Can't believe it was free! We spent at least a couple of hours just admiring the many wonderful Art Works and contemporary art and statues etc.

Good cross section of artists represented. There are quite a few impressionist paintings that I was surprised to see in this museum. It is free entrance but maybe it was the season (summer ending), there did not seemed to have air condition except in a few galleries. Still a nice visit - especially where it is located, reachable via the "subte" easily.

Wow don't miss it. In my six visits to Buenos Aires for some reason I never made it to this wonderful museum. It free to enter and the collection is amazing of both Argentinian artists and international artists. I think it requires more than one visit and I'm goin back soon. There's no cafe in the museum but a couple of great restaurants behind.
Art. A LOT of Art, and all for free! Great variety of wellknown artist, perect place to wander on a rainy day.

Great place on a humid day. At least this place is well air conditioned in a city which can be very humid.The works of art may not be top class, but there's enough choice to spend one or two hours and admire the very fair cross section of world Art. Many of the works could have been improved in their presentation by better lighting, but do not despair the trip here, in a very central but un crowded part of the City was worth while

Good collections - check the website first. The MNBA is free to the public, and apparently under budget cuts in the new government. No plans of the museum were available, and so visiting the galleries was very hit or miss. We'd been there before and were still puzzled. Worth a visit just for the battle paintings by Camilio Lopez, who lost an arm in the wars of the late 19th century but managed to convey with paint what war is like. (To the right in the entrance hall) - Warning - in the area there are thieves who specialize in squirting you with salad dressing or the like and then offering to help you clean up, allowing them to steal your belongings. Even though we knew about this for years it happened ot us today. Just pay attention as you walk in tourist areas and don't let anyone get very close to you, even if you have to stop cold and make them go past.

Interesting. This Museum is relevant to get acquanited with Argentinian artists throughout the centuries. There are also works by European and other foreign artists. We were there on a Sunday and enjoyed a free guided visit, although a little crowded it was fun and informative.
Excellent Art Museum in a beautiful area. If you are into arts and appreciate museums, this is a can't miss. Very nice museum in one of the prettiest areas of the city.
From Renaissance to Modern. I was surprised at the range of excellent art exhibits in the museum. Great that it is free and opened late. Went there after general city and walking tours.

The MET of Buenos Aires. If you visit one museum in BA, make it this one. Home to numerous Masters - sculptures, paintings, etc. There are a large number of Argentinian artists represented here - both old and modern. While some exhibits are permanent, there are several rotating exhibits as well - these typically encompass more modern art from the mid-20th century onward. Also, the building itself is a work of art.

Good overview of European and American art throughout the centuries. We enjoyed the layout and atmosphere in the museum. We went to see Argentinian painters, and there are some. The museum covers medieval art up until contemporary art, of which there are a few bits.
Great paintings.... Well displayed works of art (paintings). The admission is FREE, which was a nice surprise. Take your time, and enjoy...
beautiful. great paintings from wonderful artist. Lovely to stroll around. Very easy to get to and right nearby a small mall.
Great examples of Argentine buildings. The building has great history and the architecture stands the time. Many upheavals, riots, juntas here.

Very good collection of paintings. I visited the museum while they were renovating, a year ago. The museum is not very well organized, probably due to the renovation. The best news is that it is a quite a small museum with great paintings so you do not have to suffer in order to see good art. It as also not congested and you can appreciate the works quietly and spend as much time as you want without being pushed away by tour guides and loud groups. Great.

Worth one or two hours to walk through. We recently spent about two hours walking through the museum. There is much art from Argentina, but a nice room with a wide range of good 20th century European art and some early Northern European art. It's free, so hard to complain about it. The weather was hot so it was nice to be inside, out of the sun too.

Great museum.. Perfect size museum not too large not too small with a varied collection of international and Argentinian art. Visited it twice. Once for the lower floor a second time for the upper floor.
Outstanding collection of European Masters. We were amazed by the number of European masters included in this collection Degas, Van Gogh, Renoir, Rembrandt, Monet and much more. Free admission

Escaping a shower at the museum. Following lunch it looked as if it was going to rain and as we were near the museum decided to visit in order to avoid getting wet.What a good decision this gallery has numerous works of art from well known European artists and although our visit was short we thoroughly enjoyed our time in this excellent facility

Art gallery. First rate art gallery in buenos aires . Probably the best gallery in the city. Definitely worth a visit. Lots of Latin American art but also a good collection of leading European artists including Renoir , degas, Toulouse Latrec and many others.

Picasso and many many more for Free! . Spent a couple hours at this beautiful Art Museum and it was one the coolest things I did in BA. I got to to see a piece by Picasso and lots more amazing art work from local and global artists. Must go if you're in BA and best of all it is Free!

Excellent after refurbishment. The gallery has undergone a major (much needed) renovation and now shows off its incredible collection of mainly European and Latin American art incredibly well. Their collection of impressionist / post-impressionist paintings is quite remarkable.

Good collection, worth a visit. A very good collection from all periods including a lot of South American artists. The special exhibition of Roberto Plate was colourful and modern. It is bigger than you expect and free! Easy to spend a quick few minutes escaping from the heat or a couple of hours. Very close to Recoleto cemetery . Does not open til 12.30 so do not turn up early! Recommended.

Some collection. Free to get in. Open after midday 30. A substantial collection of western impressionists including Van Gogh, Toulouse Lautrec, Manet, Monet and Rodin's 'The Kiss'. A good collection of Argentinian artists and explanations of art history in both Spanish and English. Well worth a visit and close to the Recoleta cemetery and the Plaza Naciones Unidas with the opening and closing flower sculpture (Floralis Generica)

Free admission and photos allowed!. It's hard not to like an art museum that is free and allows photography. But then to find that it has a decent collection of French impressionist and modern art as well a collection of Argentinian art makes it even better! This is a well-curated, clean and modern museum worth a visit. The only reason I gave it a 4 instead of a 5 is because it's collection is not as extensive as some European museums I've been to (Louvre, Prado, National Gallery).

Free and Great!!. On weekends it closes late. All of the greats are inside. The museum is smart because they mix local artists with the masters. Many of the local artists are unknown to the outside world and so this made their works very interesting since they often worked side by side with the different movements such as Cubism, Impres...etc....
Wonderful gallery . Definitely worth a visit. It's free, and has an eclectic collection of mixed European and South American art. Stunning Gauguin, and a great Rothko and Sorollas.

High quality, if somewhat limited collection -- too bad the government fired the English speaking guide. This was a pleasant museum, with a high quality if somewhat limited collection. Unfortunately, our guidebook had alerted us to an English speaking tour on certain days -- but, when we got there, we were told that the guide for the English tour (and the guide for the Portuguese tour) had both been released as part of recent government cutbacks. +
Stunning art. It was wonderful seeing the evolution of Argentinian art. Museum is well organized and easy to follow.

Wonderful collection. So enjoyed the collection. A very nice mix of European Masters and Argentinian painters. Also the special exhibit of Roberto Plate was very enjoyable. The museum is free to all visitors. Unfortunately all verbiage was in Spanish. I would have been happy to have paid to have an English translation or a head set option to enhance my visit. That being said if you enjoy art it is still worth the visit. You are able to take pictures so I will do my own follow up research.
Why aren't South American artists better known in the US?. This museum has a nice collection of European art, but I recommend it mainly for its exhibits of wonderful artists from South America.
Beautiful. Just a fantastic way to spend an afternoon. Great area too so that is half then fun. Highly recommend.

Beautiful Collection. The museum is very easy to visit - the size of the collection is quite manageable. Location is very close to Recolletta Cemetery and there is no entrance fee. There are both European and Argentinian artists displayed and most likely a special exhibit of some kind.
Give it an hour. Not a bad museum, just not too much of a collection. It is on the way to a lot of places so it is worth a visit. No English maps, guides or tours on our visit.

Great art.The section showcasing modernArgentinian Artists is excellent. Worth the visit. It is very near Recoleta and the Recoleta Cementery. This museum features great art from European artists such as Monet, Gaugin, Tolouse-Lautrec. It also showcased a modern Argentinian artist. The museum is free of charge.
Quick run thru all it merits. Some European art, lots of medieval Art good special exhibit no really great work of art make this ok for a quick race thru! 22 galleries are easy to quickly survey.

Excellent art to be found here. Who would have though that so many European masters were to be found in these halls. Rembrandt, Renoir, Monet, Goya, Kandinsky, ...
There are some wonderful works here. There's also some more modern art that I do not appreciate, but others may do so.
There are some sculptures, and many bronzes. All worth a look.

Some fabulous paintings but not easy to navigate . The gallery is 10 minutes walk from the cemetery so you can combine both visits.
It has some extremely good European paintings but everything is in Spanish and there is no effort made to give any information at all about the collection which leaves visitors uninformed and underwhelmed.
On a positive note - it's free!

Interesting attempt to relate art movements to political situations. Very nice museum with Argentinian, BA, and some international artists. Beautiful well maintained museum. English signage introduced their main collection rooms but I would have liked an audio tour or a little more info for each piece of art.

Between 3 and 4 stars. Since I was a child I am used to visit important museums and I am very used to the quality of museums in Italy. Said that, it is always a bit hard for me to be astonished whilst visiting museums abroad. Nevertheless, I never lose the hope :). The museum "de Bellas Artes" encompasses an "excursus" across the centuries with some masterpiece from Picasso, Rubens, Modigliani, De Chirico with a special focus on the evolution of painting in Argentina across the centuries as well. I liked very much the artist Berni (from Argentina), who was reallz a pleasant discovery for me. The nice thing is that the museum is completely free!

This Museum Blew My Mind!. I entered with neutral expectations. It was free after all, and I had never heard anything about it. Photos were allowed, as long as no flash was used. It was 2 floors and not overwhelming in size. I expected to see art by artists I had never heard of..... Room one started with Goya and Titian. By the 3rd room, I was bug eyed as every single painting was done by a painter I recognized. Furthermore, entire rooms were credited to private collections, donated upon the death of the patron. Several Rodin sculptures graced one room and here I saw my first 2 "live" Bouguereau. The last room was filled with Argentinian masterpieces and we did not even get to the second floor where there is a Manet exhibit. I will go next week before returning to Montreal.
A great venue!. The very best "buy" in Buenos Aires. Free entrance is just the beginning...see some of the world renown masters and the best Argentine artists as well.

Best fine arts museum in South Americach. We spent 4 hours here and it exceeded all of our expectations!I took over 400 photos which I will load on in the next week or so. The collection is very large with several thousand paintings, ceramic pieces, and period furniture pieces. Almost all of the Impressionists are represented (Van Gogh, Pizzaro, Cassat, Monet, Renoir,Manet, etc). Miro, Picasso, Kline,Klee, and Jackson Pollock head up numerous cubists and neo modernist painters. Gauguin's Tahitian ladies stand out too!! Rodin and other famous sculptor artists are well represented. Italian and Flemish artists from 1300s up to 1600s are in the mix of painters, including famous Rennaisance artists such as Raphael. There is a very large roomful collection of Peter Paul Rubens. Rembrandts and Van Halls among others have some fine works here. There are many Goyas. Degas here along with Millet, Corot and Leger. There is also a large collection of Argentine artists shown particularly on the third floor. We saw over 100 Robert Plate paintings. I am going strictly on memory here and no doubt I have left out some very famous artists (Modigliani and Rousseau just came to mind).

START AT THE TOP. so we saw art on the top two floors that we would not have ever expected to see. impressionists and abstract art that we hadn't seen before. unbelievably there is very little security. we made two trips and it is right across the street from the sat-sunday fair. as well, there is another museum across from the fair that is of local artists. all very abstract and contemporary. the museum itself, is falling apart but must have been beautiful at one time. the art of fiber, paint, ceramic, etc. is great. so do both museums together. it's a great day if you love art and artists.

Worth the visit!. We visited the MNBA after a failed trip to the Latin American Art Museum, which was randomly closed on a Tuesday.We had just spent some time in Parque Tres de Febrero (Feb 3 Park), and the MNBA is a perfect follow-up: beauty of human creation after natural earthly beauty. (Plus, the air conditioning was a warm welcome!)I'll be the first to admit that I'm no art connoisseur. For me, this museum had a wonderful array of European and Argentinian artists, ranging from the 19th century (per museum literature; downstairs) to modern art (upstairs).I found the collection a good refresh and brush up on history, particularly on Argentina's own past, which I did not know about. There's a very interesting room of old Spanish/Argentinian "how to" diagrams ... depicting everything ranging from how to ford a river to how to catch ducks whilst riding a horse and using a stick with a noose. Due to other plans, we only spent an hour there which was too rushed. I think 2 to 2.5 would be more comfortable. Signing is predominantly only in Spanish (which is fair enough).

Best kept tourist secret. Beautiful museum of fine art. Very quiet nit a lot of tourists and entry is free, staff are helpful and there us fine collection of art, sculptures, and antique tapestry. Well worth a visit

Nice own collection. It is very well located museum in Recoleta. Free entrance.On top of the regular expositions, the museum has a nice own collection with impressionists.It is a program that can be joined with a walking in the nice neighborhood.

Wonderful Museum. We only had a short time to spend there, but thoroughly enjoyed it. We are not very knowledgeable about art, but found art by familiar European artists, and were thrilled to see them. We also quickly looked at Argentina art, and could have spent more time there. It was easy to get to from our hotel, free , and felt welcoming.

Small but impressive. This museum is free and has a very impressive collection of European and Latin American art. Staff is helpful and friendly. This is definitely worth a visit when in Buenos Aires. Allow at least two hours.

Nice museum with works of Argentine artists. This museum may not be as sleek as MALBA in the appearance, but it has a lot of works of Argentine artists from various periods that I didn't see in any other museums. The only downside was that it didn't have any English guide or brochure.
outstanding collection. Museum opens at 12:30; it is a good way to beat the heat of the day. A very large collection. Worth the visit.

great Museum in Buenos Aires. if you are in REcoleta you can not miss the Museo de Bellas artes, located in Avenida del Libertador and avenue Pueyrredon, you will find art from around the world but the most important thing are the local artists, very nice
Really Nice Museum. I spent some nice hours at the Museo Nacional de Bellas Artes. If you are an art lover, this museum is a "must see" in BA and it's FREE.

Great museum . I love this museum since I first visited it in 2008, this time we found it had grown but still you can visit it In a couple is hours, or a morning if it is your fist time around.
I particularly like the impressionist room and the second floor.

Fantastic museum . Opened usually after 12:30 pm You have more than two hours to pass on vision the history of the human art resumed on compreensive texts and review your own concepts of art. Upsters, rooms crowded with paints and scultures make you feel part of the structure of the museum.

Complete museum. For a free art museum, I was very impressed with the nice variety of artist. A beautiful Rodin statue welcomed us to one room, a Van Gogh windmill I've never seen before, a colorful Cezanne girl, elegant Degas ballerinas and some beautiful historical and detailed work by Argentinian artists. Take your time, sit down and enjoy this museum, at least two hours. Within walkable distance from many Recoleta hotels, near cemetary.
Really cool and FREE! . This is a great place to visit when wandering around BA! It is free and there is a lot of great pieces to admire. I would definitely recommend visiting this art gallery.

2 hyper elegant Modigliani pieces + others. Free admission and very courteous staff plus a credible collection that includes 2 delightful Modigliani and a sumptuously colorful Picasso. Also, the proximity of the Floralis Genérica is a great bonus as you can visit it before or afterward.
1 Van Gogh. But I had never seen it before. Small but very good museum. Takes only about an hour or two at most. Mostly focuses on modern and contempory art

Rich, interesting and free of charge!. A rich international collection of fine art, probably the largest of South America. It has inherited a number of private collections, therefore you can find here and there corners full of precolumbian pottery or graphic artworks, not integrated with the other surrounding pieces. Plenty of personnel takes good care of the numerous rooms where painings and sculptures are exposed with a good illumination. The entrance is free of charge, and there is an interesting calendar of teaching activities to be followed.

Average art museum. We needed something to do so went here. It was OK , but not comparable to other museums in the world. There is no guide to the various collections/locations, but it is small , so one can just follow the circle. A reasonable collection of the impressionists, but mostly their lesser known works. Top floor was modern Argentinean art, and we did not go there.

Great array of old maters and contemporary art on display.. This is a GEM in Buenos Aires and it's free. Exquisite old European arts, sculptures (Rodin etc) contemporary works and some Chinese arts and artefacts. Really surprised at the amount of art on offer here. There are floor guides on the layout of the art on display which makes for a better experience but it would have been better to have English explanation on the displays. Now I know I am being pedantic but that apart, it's worth seeing.Don't be perturbed by the over eager guards as they will tell you to move back if you are too close to the exhibits.I will recommend visiting this museum .

An astonishing array of classics and some terrific contemporary art. Rodin, Cezanne, Gaugin, Degas, Lautrec, Pissarro, Van Gogh, Monet, Delacroix and that was just in the first two rooms of this massive museum, which also houses ancient Chinese urns, the work of a wide array of South American artists, contemporary art and much much more. If you are an art lover, this is a place to come to discovery some artists that may be new to you as well as to see works by well-known artists. Well worth the visit.

Great museum, from European renaissance through to 21st century latin American art. Great Museum, manageable size. Much better than MALBA.
Well set out. Fun. Had a Goya exhibition when we were there. Opens late. Highly recommended.

Great collection of European Art and it's FREE!. Great collection on the ground floor of European Art. Argentinean art is located on level 3 - small 'interesting' collection. Entry is free, opened til 9pm on a Saturday and it is a short walk from the Recoleta area. So you could pop to the Museum at about 6pm on a Saturday and then head for dinner after. If you are on the painful Hop on/off bus, get off at the Flower stop (stop 15) and walk across the park to the Museum. This will save you having to do all the stops until you get to the Museum (stop 23) - so a good 45 minutes would be saved, Definitely, worth a visit.!

The masters without the queues. What a gem of a museum. First of all its FREE. However most importantly it has a fine collection of old and contemporary masters through which you can trace the history of Western Art. I had time to sit and contemplate the Renoir, Monet's, Pollack etc with no one else in the room. Anywhere else in the world and your shuffling past the pictures following a crowd. If your interested in art the publicity is spot on. The best collection of Western Art in South America!

Very Fine Art. What a fantastic discovery!The best selection of Rodin I have seen outside of Paris. Loved seeing three Renoir works and several Degas. Even a Marc Chagall to round the day off.We spent two hours here and could have spent even longer but it was about to close.Best Art Gallery in South America that I have seen so far.A must visit in Buenos Aires

Good for a visit but no blown away....not an officionado of art though.. We had read all the reviews and thought this would be a good place to while away a few hours. We found it a bit dark albeit I understand that's essential for some of the pieces. The walls were pretty random colours that I don't think totally enhanced the paintings. I'm more into sculptures though and thought they had some really fine pieces. If you know your art you may enjoy it more but it just didn't rock my boat. Still worth the visit though.

Worth an hour or two. The art throughout the museum is as expected - examples from most major periods with a little more emphasis on national artists. It has a solid mix of 2D and 3D works from South American and European artists. The collection is a fraction of the quantity and quality of any of the major European art museums (Rijksmuseum, Louvre, Prado, the Vatican, etc), but it would be unfair to expect and hold this museum to such an international standard.This is a free museum that is definitely worth a quick stroll through, to see if you find a work or two from your favorite artist, or maybe discover a new artist that catches your eye. It can be seen from bottom to top in maybe two hours.

Fine Art. The Museum of Fine Arts has a very good permanent collection including impressionist art by Latin American's and Europeans. Some lovely Degas works, Monet and Gaugin. Worth the time to visit. No english guides. Free admission. May be closed on Mondays.
Art for Real Art Lovers. Interesting if you are a real art lover or have a particular interest in Religious or Argentinian Art.
What a collection!. We have seen many musea around the globe, but were never so impressed by a collection. AND FOR FREE! From old to new, name a big name and you find it here. Highly reccomended

Two hours well spent.. Great Modigliani (two), Degas (a lot), Manet, Rembrandt (just one but of high quality) and very good Argentinian artists. Nicely exhibited art, intimate feel, and the open terraces on the top level, with some sculpture there. Free of charge.

World Class Art Museum. This was not my first time at this Museum and I was able to see different art masterpieces from different movements. If you visit you're able to see works of Masters such as Picasso, Monet, Manet, Corot, Rothko, Pollock, etc. And also some of the greatest painters of Argentinian Art such as Berni, Xul Solar, De La Carcova, Quinquela Martin, Prilidiano Pueyrredon, etc.. Must see and is also a choice for cloudy/rany days. Close to the Floralis Generica and Recoleta Cemetery.
Definitely worthwhile. A nice collection of European and South American art. Free admission is a plus! Well worth a few hours of your time if you are visiting Buenos Aires.
Great museum and FREEEEEE. Wonderful museum in Recoleta - lots of great art. Very enjoyable way to spend a couple of hours, especially if it is really hot or rainy outside :).

Great Art. I had to stretch my appreciation for what is art when viewing some of the pieces located here. However, there are so many rich and wonderful pieces to view and appreciate that the visit was worth it.

A must see average art museum. This is a national art museum so in rating it I must compare it to other like national and important world museums. In comparison Museo Nacional de Bellas Artes is just average. Yet it is a must see for anyone visiting Buenos Aires who appreciates the arts! Excellent collections from a broad spectrum of Argentina's artists covering the entire timeline of the country. Bellas Artes also has extensive exhibits of European art from 16th century to present. Modern art is also adequately represented. A well organized and very good museum that recognizes its important cultural role by having free admissions. Many of the art descriptions are written in both Spanish and English. Prepare to spend 2 to 3 hours to see all exhibits. Recommended
Art. One of the best small museums I have visited well organized and interestingly arranged we came on a free Sunday easily accessible
Just a good way to get a feel for the city. Sort of standard city museum but very helpful security who were able to answer questions. Allow an hour.

Great collection, take the English tour on Tues/Thurs. I really enjoyed this art museum. They offer a free English tour on Tuesdays and Thursdays which last about an hour. Also, the second floor has been renovated and offer some signage in English. Worth a trip especially on a rainy day.

Outstanding collection and not to be missed!. If you enjoy 19 and 20 century art, then don't miss the opportunity to see works by some of the most famous European artists. There is a particularly large collection os French impressionists.Entrance is free and the gallery is open until 8 pm on most evenings.

not a word in english. the collection is fine even though I was expecting more. the pitty is that you will not find even a word of information in english. all is in spanish only. that means you can only have a look at the paintings which are of course great.
Free entry!. If you are European, the top two floors are the most interesting as they show Latin American art. The two roof terraces offer a nice view.

Can't believe it is free!. Excellent variety in the collection. Old masters, impressionists and a floor of Latin American art. Some very dark Argentinian pieces and some very interesting modern art. Definitely worth a visit if you like art at all, or want to know a bit more about Argentinian art. Well laid out. There is some English explanations. Very nice park setting..

Wonderful free museum!. The museum is closed on Mondays. You can't miss seeing this pink colored building that used to be the city's waterworks. Many of the European artists are represented: Manet, Degas, Monet, Gaugin, Toulouse-Lautrec, El Greco, Rubens, Rembrandt,and Goya. There are several wings that house contemporary artists. The Argentine art is grouped according to decades. It was a very well presented museum with brochures in English which is always appreciated.

A nice collection and free. You can easily walk here from Recoleta. I enjoyed this museum. The collection shows the influences older masters must have had on the Argentinian culture but also highlights some local artists that create a good mix of known and probably new to you. There are three floors and then there is the roof that has an excellent view of the faculty of Bellas Artes and the flower sculpture that opens up in the sun and closes in the shade. I went to several museums in Buenos Aires and this is one of the most substantial. I love it that it is free. This is a city that really makes culture accessible to its people.

Very representative museum. If you like 19th C. European Art and a good selection of Argentinian artists, this is your place. Lots of Impressionists and other European artists, as well as South American

A quick taste of BS's fine arts. The Museo Nacional de Bellas Artes is a great place. The collection isn't huge so you can spend your time taking in each of the pieces without getting overwhelmed. The collection included some conventional pieces, as well as other's that were quite unique and made the experience more interesting.

A must-see attraction. The museum counts with a very beautiful art collection and charges nothing to be visited. It's located in Recoleta and within a walking distance from the famous cemetery where Eva Perón is buried.

I don't know why - but I really didn't like this place!. There is a very comprehensive and sometimes interesting collection here. The curation is irritating - the more contemporary exhibits are upstairs in bright and spacious galleries - the ground floor is for the older pieces. On the ground floor the curation is strictly by date and also works are displayed in the style of their period and this is infuriating. Some of the 19th century galleries are so crammed it is difficult to enjoy the individual pieces. The museum has a lot of fabulous content - the curators seem determined to ensure you don't enjoy it too easily!

Free traditional style art gallery. Set in a lovely building, the art collection was a pleasant mix of old masters, European and Argentinian, some statues, tapestries and ornate objets d'art and furniture. Free entry. Allowed to take photos without flash and a backpack, as long as it was on my chest, not my back.

Thoughtful presentation of an admirable collection. I learned much from the few hours spent in the halls of the museum. Curators wove historical events and artistic achievement into an understanding of the role of art as both reflection and advocacy. However, if you never read the first line of the bilingual notes, you would find remarkable company in artists from four centuries to be seen and enjoyed.

must see it!. This is my favorite museum much better than the Louvre in Paris and free!There were so many artefacts that it was overwhelming. Nice collections from Europe (Monet, Picasso, Rodin, Shagall, Toulouse-Lautrec etc) and nice&huge collection from South-America. Frankly, I wanted to cry from pleasure when I saw their collections, unbelievable!I love this place, I walked so long inside the museum that I had pain in my legs.Only inconvenient: you have to wear you backpack on your chest.

Excellent art collection!. This art gallery is a must see in Buenos Aires. It is also located a short walk from the Recoleta Cemetery and a collection of good cafes as well as the Recoleta neighbourhood, so you can make a day out of it. On Sunday's there is also usually an outdoor craft market located across the street.Free admission. Try to go when there is a special exhibition as there is the equivalent of a third floor in the large exhibition areas at the back that house the special exhibits. Main floor has a good international collection representing a variety of artists, techniques and periods, and the upper floor has a collection of Argentinean art and sculpture. The exhibits on parts of the main floor change over time, so it is worth going back on subsequent visits to Buenos Aires.Definitely recommended.
Great free museum. Nice place to spend a rainy day! Great selection of all types of art. Nice selection of Latin art. You could spend half a day

Don't bother taking the guided tour. The tour may try too much to bring context about the local painters and the historical events they depicted. Too much information for tourists, the tour should touch on the whole museum and just provide some additional focus on the local artists. Those interested can ask for more/ spend more time in the respective museum sections/ visit MALBA. But the MNBA is first an arts museum, not a history one.

A place not to be missed!. This beautiful building holds the largest public collection of Latin America with over 12,000 pieces of art. Walk along 25 exhibition halls, offers a guided english tour and admission is free!

Interesting museum. It's definitely worth the price of admission -- IT'S FREE.The collection covers western art but is light on major works. The Impressionists have interesting unfinished works displayed.
cool art museum. in front of the beautiful art-fair of Recoletta- you find this gem. the museum offers a chance to see beautiful piecse, classic and modern and Sundays is free

Solid museum. Nice museum to visit. tries hard to be a major museum, but doesn't have the collection for it. A couple of pieces here and there by European masters. Would be wonderful if it focused on Argentine and south American art instead. A interesting section is a private collection donated to the museum, containing some wonderful pieces and artifacts. Worth a visit on a rainy day.
Average but free. There isn't much to see. They do have some nice Argentinian art (Pueyrredon in particular), so worth seeing if you have a lot of time in BsAs, but not a "must see."

Interesting Modern Art. There is a good selection of art from the 16th century right up to the 1990s, and it has free entry. The roof terrace is quiet. My only complaint is the paucity of descriptions in english.

Good museum. Free entry. I'm a firm believer that museum should all be free but sometimes when they are they end up being crap. This is not the case with this museum. It has an excellent span of art through out the ages and many pieces of Argentine pieces as week as some work by Italian, French and Spanish artists
Great museum. We really liked the exhibits that they had; this is a fabulous place for anyone who appreciates art to visit.

Best place to go!. Wonderful museum! Plenty of art of artistes from all around the world. Really great museum, it was the beat place i've been in Buenos Aires. i went one saturday and it was free to enter (it opens at 9:30), I don't know how does it work the others days.

Magnificent!. After visiting the MALBA museum several blocks away, this museum came as a total refreshing change. Most of the famous artists in the world have collections here. This is what I expected from a true museum which included no admission charge. You must attend if in Buenos Aires.
Refurbished and newly wonderful. After several years of dingy, musty suffering, this jewel has been buffed and reborn. It is a must-see in the city.
Free and worth a visit . Good paintings and sculptures. Free and we enjoyed our visit. Note only opened after 12.30pm so we missed it the first day we passed.

A World Class Art Museum. Lovely, well laid out museum with a surprisingly good Impressionistic collection stocked with a few Monets, Renoirs and even a Van Gogh. The other sections were mostly Argentine painters, but were excellent in their own right. It was free to enter and we spent an enjoyable hour and a half inside. It is also right around the corner from the Pilar Basilica and the Recoleta Cemetery which made for a great five hours of high quality tourist sights.

Fantastic deal. I went on Wednesday prepared to pay half price and find out it was absolutely free. I love first floor with more traditional artist Picasso.Chagall, Goya, Modigliani just to mention few. Also visual and light art upstairs was nice. Over all I was pretty impressed

Delightful. Really lovely museum with a surprisingly fine haul o f good paintings and even free to get in.Good feel all round and great to see so many school kids enjoying the artistic heritage of the country

"Our" museum. The Belle Artes Museum was at the end of our street, so needless to say my husband and I spent many hours surrounded by the art that is a permanent part of the collection as well as loaned collections that were wonderful. No matter if you are just visiting and haven't much time, a half hour or more will be worth the memories you will have .
a must see. get to see great art for free! it´s a lovely place for everyone who likes to have a widde view of the diferent arts from all over the world

Nice Place to visit. Some very nice art and easy to see. A few European pieces by impressionist. Located near the famous metal "flower" as well. Cannot really say its a world class museum but still interesting if in the area and looking for things to do.. Great rainy day stop.

This would be my first choice as museums in Buenos Aires. Definitely my first choice when it comes to museums in BA - it has classic art and modern as well. The impressionists are here - Manet, Monet, Renoir, Sisley, but also Chagall, Modigliani, Rodin, Toulouse-Lautrec. You should reserve at least 4 hours for this one. The good news is that is part of free Night Museums circuit if in the area on Oct 31st.
Amazing experience. This is an amazing place to experience beautiful exhibits. Considering that entrance is free, this must be in the definite list of everyone visiting Buenos Aires
A lot of the greats in here! A must-see!. Entry is gratis, and I totally recommend this museum! A lot of big names in here! VanGogh, Rembrandt just to name a few, and Argentine artists as well!

Very Satisfying Half Day for Art Lovers. A very good, medium-sized museum covering a variety of periods from Impressionism and Post-Impressionism to Baroque and French academic painting featuring a healthy sampling of great artists like Rembrandt, Van Gogh, Goya, Gaugin, Monet, Manet, Degas, Zurburán, Bouguereau, and, of course, Rodin, who had such a special affinity for Buenos Aires that he had a "Thinker" made especially for the city, which you should keep an eye out for in the park in front of the Congressional building. And the museum also houses, of course, the work of preeminent Argentine artists as well.Free to visit, this makes for a nice half day, followed or preceded by a stroll in the surrounding park and a visit to the Floralis Genérica.

The fact that it's free makes it a must-see!. This museum is close to the recoleta area and is filled with many beautiful and interesting art pieces including sculptures, paintings and tapestries. You can walk right up or the artwork which is incredible. There are many pieces by world famous artists including Monet, Degas, Rodin and others. We didn't spend a lot of time here but it was definitely worth a visit.
Bellas Artes Museum. Beautifully restored building with a nice collection of art...perfect for a rainy day or while strolling through Recoleta.. and its free!

Splendid. This is a highly pleasant museum to visit. It is middle-sized, so the complete tour can be made in a single (long) visit and it is well organized, with human sized rooms each with its own topic. The Museum covers an extensive diversity of periods and styles from European 16th Century to Argentinian recent works. Explanations are succinct but to the point and not pretentious, additional information is available via your smartphone for a number of items. The first floor is mostly European with works from all great artists from Rembrandt to Picasso and from Monet to Rothko (admittedly only one or two of each and not their masterworks but still an impressive coverage). Rodin is also present with a number of sculptures. The second, and small third, floors are mostly Argentinian, with works of various interest but still quite educative. We loved the unstressed atmosphere and pleasant visit: this an excellent stop in Buenos Aires. Entry is free, a nice restaurant is on the back (sponsored by a German carmaker!)
Good collections. Not a huge gallery but some nice pieces and its very well laid out inside.well worth a visit, there is also an nice outside space on the roof.

Great surprise - a must for every art lover !!!. Fantastic museum with first class collection. Middle size - very pleasant to visit. Excellent paintings and sculptures ( from Middle Ages to modern art ) - you can find Rembrandt, El Greco, Velazquez, Zurbaran, Goya, Corot, Monet, Manet, Renoir, Modigliani and many others...a must for art lovers!

Nice medium size museum in Recoleta. It is not a huge museum, but they have some surprising paintings from masters such as Degas, Monet, Manet and Toulouse Lautrec. Even a number of Dutch masters. I found most attractions on the lower level; the upper lever with argentinian artists was not impressive at all. Entrance is free. Good to combine with a visit to other Recoleta attractions such as the famous cemetary or La Biela cafe.

Easily combined with other museums. Visiting this museum may be combined with a visit of the MALBA (Museum of latin american art), the Museo Nacional De Arte Decorativo, the Palais De Glace, the CCR (Centro Cultural Recoleta) and the Biblioteca Nacional which are all located close to it. The MNBA opened quiet a few new display areas recently and has a movie theatre, too (entrance on the back side of the building).

Excellent cross section of Latin American and other art. It wasn't huge and sprawling like the Louvre, or the Prado. But has wonderful things in it. I really liked that they made space for school classes. In one area, the kids were participating in poetry karaoke, with Argentinian poets as the "music". Great lay out. Not too tiring.
Average museum. This is an average museum. Only come here if it is a rainy day and you have nothing else better to do .

Not to miss this one. A very nice building and we like the collection the had on display. We needed more than 3 hours to do al of the rooms and it was worth the time. Surprise to see also some dutch masters
Skip the European Art if you are "Western". We had a guided tour in English of the Argentinian Art as it related to their own story towards nationhood.
Excellent museum. We had a wonderful visit to this fabulous museum. It was free to visit and had spectacular works of art including Monet, Degas, Renoir etc.
Pleasant. Quite extensive and informative art museum. Just beware that it is far from metro (buses operate frequently though), and does not open until noon.
Don't miss this museum. No one can miss a visit to this lovely museum. I truly enjoyed range of art from the Mark Rothko and other modern artists to the more traditional Argentine artists.

Must visit this in Buenos Aires. A must-see in Buenos Aires. It´s been reorganised, and there are several gems (a Gauguin and a Van Gogh included). There usually are tours for kids (parents can walk along or do their own tour). There is no shop to buy souvenirs or books. But around the block you can find the MNBA Association, with a small shop. Keep in mind this shop is closed on weekends.
Nice surprise. Was a nice surprise. Close to the Giant Flower, free entrance and nice local collection of arts. Service is ok and team very helpful.

Activities for rainy days in Buenos Aires. Buenos Aires is a great city for cycling or food tours, but things get tricky when it rains. The Museo Nacional de Bellas Artes is a great place to spend a rainy afternoon. The museum features a variety of famous international artists - from Argentina as well as elsewhere. The museum is small enough that it is not overwhelming and has a great 'vibe' to it. It is easy to get to, easy to get tickets and worth the pleasant experience. I also very much loved the pink colour, remaining me of the Pink Palace in a different part of town, not too far away.
average. this is an average art museum, nothing special, you won't miss much if you don't go there, mostly paintings

Great museum free so defo worth a visit. Great museum, free to visit and really nice selection of different styles of art, we went on a thursday and it seemed they had a party on the terrace and beers but it was so jam packed and all the security were really iratly telling you not to walk in the lines...but a lot of fun
Beautiful museum. Beautiful museum, important works from some of the great masters. There was no entry fee, so there is no excuse to miss this if around the neighbourhood.
Interesting and Free!. When I visited they had an´ Él Greco´ expsosition which was really interesting. It has a good layout. The art gives a good insight into Argentinian history. Go!

Argentinean and European masters for free. The newly renovated Museo of Bellas Artes has an interesting collection of European masters and Argentinean art. The first floor has Degas, Corot, Tolouse-Lautrec, some Spanish masters, lots of Rodin, one minor Van Gogh, etc. The second floor, just opened, has a collection in chronological order of the main Argentinean art currents, including some minor works of world masters such as Picasso, Chagall, etc. The Berni room is unmissable, and the modern works (from the 1950s and on) are pretty good. There is also a third floor with some contemporary local art. The temporary exhibits are generally excellent (you enter them from the first floor); nowadays there is a very interesting exhibit on Paraguayan Indian artistic expressions.
