Did I mentioned that the place is free of charge? There is wi-fi on the main entrance and a free locker. There are worse ways to spend a couple of hours than looking at world-class art.
Outstanding Collection !. The largest art collection in Latin America including outstanding paintings from the most famous painters in the world...

Excellent Fine Art Museum. This was an amazing museum located a short distance from our hotel in Recolleta. It has great masters and wonderful Argentinian artists. The museum was free and very well laid out.

Great experience. I visited this museum during a business trip. It is for free and has a lot of interesting art displayed. The staff was very friendly and helpful. You can find it easily due to its color and spend e.g. 45 minutes and enjoy the beautiful paintings. Great for rainy weather and for a restroom stop, too.
So huge!. I did the little visit they prepared for Brazilians with a part of the argentinian art, the beginning of it. I liked it. Go with time because it is huge.

Not so rich collection with few masters. Museo Nacional de Bellas Artes is the most famous museum that holds a collection of 15th-18th centuries' artists in Buenos Aires. You can see few paintings from Monet, Cezanne, Van Gogh, Rubens, Rembrandt each. There is also a big part of th museum that is dedicated to Argentinian art. If you have a habit to visit those type of museum or if you are a art history student, it is must, otherwise you can pass it. It is so close to Recoleta, just down the road, 5 mins by walk.

A national gallery with national focus but international works. A good collection of european and argentinian art, including some outstanding impressionist works. Well worth a brief visit to understand how connected to the wider art community the LAC region is.
Better than I expected. Worth a visit. It is free to enter and they have some great pieces of art work and some interesting exhibits.
A Very Solid Museum...Worth a few hours.. A very solid museum that offers a great overview of the history of art in Argentina with enough international pieces to give you a solid context.
Classic art museum. Nice collection of European and some South American paintings and sculptures composed in chronological order.
Beautiful museum. A surprising range of European art plus an exhibit on the disappearing indigenous tribes of the rain forest. Loved it! Highly recommended!

Lovely museum with familiar impressionist and other art.. This museum has lots of pieces by famous impressionist painters. Lots of Rodin pieces, also. Most viewers will love this museum and recognize art by Degas, Monet, and the like. When we went only the first floor was open awaiting the reopening by the President of Argentina later that week. So, there's lots we didn't see.

The museum of fine arts is a beautiful building outside both outside and inside. There aren't that many items on display, one can easily spend half an hour to an hour at most to finish the tour of the museum. One nice thing about it is free of charge and a good location
Nice museum to inject a bit of culture between 2 steaks !. Enjoyable visit even if only the first floor was opened to the public, nice eclectic collection, recommended
Great Free Museum. Was shocked this place was free since I liked it better than MALBA. Lots of interesting displays and good works. It is free, but it's not in English...
Culture trip. Great place to visit and relax- History well explained . Situated in a wonderful city with great people
Do it!. It'll take you 2 hours max to cover its permanent collection which I found rich and attractive - Well curated museum in a great area.

You have to go.. In a week they are going to reopen the 2nd floor. It's the best argentinian museum. Don't expect european standarts, because we don't have them, but still it's beautifully shown and the collection is great.
Free and Beautiful. What's not to like? Plus, the guards are nice. They also let you take photos. You have to wear your backpack on your front though. :D
Walking and visiting Buenos Aires. Buenos Aires is a beutiful city full of life and with many churches, museums and parks to visit, easy to travel around.

A multi-faceted collection. It is a large collection with a wide range of artwork...paintings by Argentinian artists...paintings across the spectrum of art...lots of great sculpture pieces...however, some are lesser works by the greats...
Good Variety. Great variety of European and South American works. Sculpture collection is quite nice as well. Only drawback: Very hot in winter (TIP: leave your heavy coat at home).
Enjoy the paintings. Great collection of paintings but the curation is poor. The Argentine room is an eyesore - please avoid this one if you want to escape a headache.
worth your time. has some art that makes your time worth the visit. The large pink building is easy to spot from the street.
Great Art. The place was under construction so they didn't have a lot of its content open to the public. Still, it was a short but nice visit.

Tourism. The museum has many wonderful paintings painted by Degas, Monet, Sisley, and even one Van Gogh. All art periods are covered, including the early 14th century. There are also several paintings painted by Argentinean artists.

No English tours until August. This is a wonderful museum but don't go expecting the English tour. We have tried twice in the past week. Tuesday we were told the tour guide was ill and today were told there woudl be no tours in English until August. FYI.

Not the best art museum. This museum highlights European are more than their own (which is very well exhibited at the Coleccion de Arte Amalia de Fortabat in Pureto Madero).
Their European collection is not spectacular, and there is not a comprehensive representation of their own art.

good prives collectión.. There are one pictur of each period and painter, but, poor show off, no flowers, etc.
bad toilletes.
now coffe shop inside.
poor gifs to buy.

Surprisingly great museum. I did not expected, by any chance to attend such a great collection, with Nordic artist, some argentinian, and some impresionist. Exhibition is organized, ambiance is great, is missing the communication from the curator to the public, also missing reading material, brochures, etc.
Overall great exhibition, specially for the work donated by the Hirsh family.

Great free museum in Recoleta. NIce museum in recoleta. Definitely a stop you should make while walking around. Located near the Recoleta Cemetary on the other side of the park. Free museum so why not stop in!
If you like art you will love this place. It's full of paintings made by great artists, If you like art this place is a hidden gem in the big city of Buenos Aires. Totally recommend this museum!

A surprising gem of a museum. With so many other attractions in Buenos Aires to see, we enjoyed our visit. It was raining, so the trip was a relief from the wet. What a surprise to see so many beautiful paintings of the sixteenth, seventeenth, and eighteenth centuries. I am a French Impressionist fan, so I enjoyed the collection with included Manet, Corbet, Van Gogh, and others.
A great cultural experience. We went back twice just to make sure we didn't miss anything. We liked the English translated information boards for each painting. And it was a free entrance!

Nice gallery. Lots of interesting art from the heyday of Argentina.
There were quite a few pieces of artwork that gave some notion of what Argentina was like historically.

Undergoing renovation currently, but still worth seeing.. The best thing about this museum is the chance to see lesser known works by some major stars from the art history constellation: Monet, Sisley, El Greco. Zuberan, de Rivera, Degas, Gaugin, to name a few.

fantastic gallery. great collection. Great collection of works, particulary French impressionist. Free entry. Well worth a visit. Some nice works of Rodin, Pissaro, VanGogh, Courbet, Sissley, Gaugin, Latour. I spent about an hour and a half here at a brisk pace. Would have liked to have a guide though, I didn't see any around, perhaps because it was a Sunday.

Pity it does not have enough money. Right in the beautifil Recoleta neighborhood, the museum houses a passable collection of European Art but a really excellent collection of pre colombian art and other of Argentine masters. The temporary exhibitions are also usually worth the visit. It is a pity it apparently doesn't have money for a good makeover on the building, which would greatly enhance the visitor's confort.
Lovely, gracious, dark, and free!. intimate, bare bones, surprisingly great examples of European artists. Not many but excellent examples from Rodin.

Lovely location for a very basic art collection. First, I admit I've been fortunate to visit some extraordinary art museums in the U.S. And Europe, so my perspective may be skewed. There are many nice paintings by unfamiliar Renaissance and 19th century painters. There are some excellent sculptures by Rodin as well. However, the museums organization can be confusing as one gallery does not necessarily flow logically into another and several "dead end" small galleries have radically different types of art from the large galleries to which they are attached. I did enjoy the Pueyrron gallery with works by a native-son of Argentina. Bottomline: don't expect a world class collection but enjoy it for what it is.

Far from Europe, a great international collection... for free. Great museum in a beautiful location to see after the visit. It has an important collection of pictures and sculptures by international artists such as Rodin, Van Gogh, Gauguin, Monet, Manet, Picasso, Kandinsky, Klee and the best locals, such as Petorutti, Alonso, Kemble, Sivori, Soldi. Of course, they usually have temporary exhibitions. Take your time, do not miss it. You will enjoy it!
Wonderful spot. Although it's been remodeled and several rooms are close to visitation, it's a must-go in Buenos Aires. Spare a couple of hours to pay this nice museum a visit.

Awesome collection, free admission!. Definitely not the Louvre or the MET, but you can easily spend a whole day here admiring their diverse exhibitions, particularly their Argentinian and 19th century European art collections. Beautiful pieces by Rodin, Goya, Rembrandt, Manet, Monet, Van Gogh, Gauguin, Degas and many more. During my visit they had an outstanding temporary exhibition from a local surrealist painter: Eugenio Cuttica. And the best part, it's free!
Breath taking. World class art, including many sculptures by Rodin, paintings by the likes of Monet, Gauguin, Van Gogh and more. I went back twice.

Grand Old Style. This museum features the usual variety of art you would find in a classic old large city museum - modern, impressionism, Renaissance, etc, plus a good representation of Argentine and Latin American art.. The building is a grand old place, with very high ceilings and large rooms lined with paintings, many with benches to sit on. Entry is free. It is a fine place to wander through and relax.Also, it is worth the visit just for its location on Ave. del Libertador, a street lined by large parklands, modern, high end condos, and upscale restaurants. This Recoleta section of the city is very much upper class Buenos Aires.

Good international collection. I really liked this museum. It's in a great pink building (you can't miss it!). It has a surprisingly large collection of European artists - I wasn't expecting that. But there is also a good selection of local artists. There is also a nice temporary exhibition space. Plus, it's free!
I'm pretty sure. that I don't get art. This museum didn't help me either. For all the other people, it seemed very nice, and I never heard of troubles happening here.

Great space, good art, great exhibition.. We were lucky to see an exhibition of the works of Eugenio Cuttica. Brilliant exhibition! The main collection is fairly big and has some nice works of art. Definitely worth a visit. Entrance is free, which is yet another nice addition, especially considering the fact that this is probably the best art museum in Buenos Aires, whereas MALBA and the Museum of Decorative Arts, among others, are not free and do not come close in value to this one.

Traditional museum. OK collection of traditional paintings and sculpture. When I was there they had an excellent photo show on the top floor. This is a must see in B.A. if you like art. Hardly avant-garde but a good review of B.A. art through the centuries.

excellent range of famous artists and thier works. exceptional , cezzane, Manet, Monet, and many many more, some superb paintings by lesser known South americans. Spend some time and enjoy, and it's free.

Fine Arts and Good Gift Shop. This is in Recoleta and easy to find - it has some interesting antiques and a small collection, it's free entry which is a bonus considering the fees in Europe/N.America. There is a core exhibition along with exhibits from Argentinian artists.There is a fine gift shop with some unusual cards/souvenirs and at reasonable prices!

Good art at Belle Art. I liked this gallery a lot. Interesting collection of European artists, particularly French, Italian and Spanish. Possibly more interesting to me was the representation of Argentinan and Sotuh American artists particularly from the last two centuries - some I was aware of and some new and discoveries. Never a shortage of statutes in Buenos Aires and BellArt had some as well.

A handful of Grand Masters for free. If you like your art then stop in for a visit to Rodin's 'The Kiss', Degas's ballet dancers, Goya, El Greco, a couple of Dutch Masters, and a few more besides as a tribute to the heydays of Argentina (i.e. when they had foreign currency). Take a moment to acknowledge a country that provides art for free to everyone -you'll probably encounter a number of school kids sketching the art and touring the museum which seems like good utility from the collection.
Interesting if you got an extra day in Buenos Aires. Well situated nearby the famous Recoleta cementery, European art from 16th, 17th, 18th and 19h century..

Great collection of Argentinean and European painting. This great museum has a very good collection of European painting, with works from the XV to the XX century masters, including a good exhibition of Impressionism and Modern painting, plus many rooms of Argentinean painting. It has a nice bar at the end of the building from where the Avenida Figueroa Alcorta and the School of Law can be admired. The surrounding parks are beautiful!

A good way to spend an hour. This is a good little museum,but it's not great by international standards. It's a fine way to spend an hour or an hour a half in a quiet place. I did enjoy the collection of paintings.

Fine arts in Recoleta. you can't miss a visit to MNBA in BsAs, if you happen to be in Recoleta. Van Gogh, Gauguin, Manet, local and international painters and sculptors, permanent collections and great temporary exhibitions make this worth a visit. Tuesday to Friday from 12:30 to 20:30 hsSaturday, Sunday from 9:30 to 20:30 hsLast Admission: 30 minutes before closingClosed on MondaysFree admission

A lovely visit. One of my more favorite museums that I have been to. Quiet and relaxing you really can take your time with the art without fighting the crowds. In the upper levels there are great temporary exhibits as well. Very near the famous La Recoletta Cemetery, its worth visiting at the same time. Great restaurants in the area can make for a wonderful late evening.

Collection worth seeing. Small collection in comparison with other capital city fine art museums. It almost tells the story of Argentine fortunes, with a very strong collection of late 19th C and early 20th C art, presumably acquired when BA was one of the world's richest cities. The display is a bit stuffy and contrasts strongly with the light-filled MALBA. There are some nice Impressionists and a wonderful painting by Toulouse-Lautrec.

Beyond expectations!!. I really wasnt expecting much, but the museum is worth visiting for sure! Its for free, you can take pictures inside and the artwork is superb, european art from 16th,17th century. It even has some paintings from such masters as Degah and Manet.Very RECOMMENDED. And it wont take you much time because its not that big, one hour is more thanenough.

lovely art work. this has some very nice art work displayed, great flow and easy to navigate without going back on yourself. my only suggestion is display the fans properly there is no point them collecting dust in a case if the are not open to admire.

Great Classical and Argentinean Art Collection. Why go to an art museum to see classical and modern art? Because while they have a small but nice collection of European art, they also have a wing dedicated to the Argentinean interpretation of Classicism and Modern movements. Nice opportunity to see how Argentinean culture adopted and adapted greek, roman, and erupoean classicism and made it their own. It gave birth to subsequent Argentinean art movements that still impact their culture today.

VERY SMALL, BUT WORTH A VISIT IF YOU GO TO THE RECOLETA CEMETARY, CLOSE BY. This is a very small Gallery, but has some excellent paintings and sculptures, beautifully displayed. Rodin, Rembrant, Corrot all there in different colour rooms absolutely accessible. You can get to within inches of rodins Kiss and see every inch and chisel mark.

Nice museum. This museum is small by some European standards, but has wonderful works by famous artists. There is an audio tour or you can wander. The area is great, close to Recoleta and shopping so it is a perfect 2 hour + diversion.

Small but lovely. This is a small museum (the second floor is currently being updated so is closed) but has a lovely collection. I would have liked more South American art but the basis of the collection was the collections of wealthy families more interested in European art.
Beautiful Art. This museum had beautiful artwork from the renaissance and classical periods, and best of all was free! We really enjoyed our time wandering around the galleries.
Free and Famous Artists. Lots of cool art to check out. The period is best be described as old. Picasso, Monet, Goya, and others on exhibit.
Worth a visit. It was a total surprise to discover world's famous pieces of art, get aqcuainted with the argentinean art. Well worth half of the day on your trip

Outstanding Collection. The Museo Nacional de Bellas Artes in Buenos Aires is a wonderful place to spend a couple of hours. The collection of works by some of the world's most outstanding masters are on display. This museum has no entry fee and is a short walk from the Recoleta Cemetery. Highly recommended, you will not be disappointed.

Must See for Art Lovers - Others Could Pass. I personally love to visit the "main" art museum in any city I visit and I thoroughly enjoyed this one. It is relatively small so it doesn't take all day to refresh your eyes with some beautiful art. As others mention, there is a fair amount of second tier art by masters but still nice to see. When I went, they had a special exhibition of Erotic Art - hard not to enjoy that! For people who aren't really into art and art museums in general, it might not be worth the stop.

Worth a Visit but More for Argentinian Art. OK, this isn't the Met or the Louvre, but it is a pretty nice regional museum. Some of the Argentinian artists are quite interesting. The issue really is that Argentina didn't have a Frick or a JPMorgan to go to Europe and bring back first rate paintings. (Or I suppose a Bernard Berenson either.) So, the non-Argentinian artists are often second tier paintings of first rate artists. But it is free, and pretty interesting an worth a peek.
Fantastic!!!. Their collection is just amazing!I was there for just two hours.... wish I had had more time, the place is worth at least an afternoon for a proper visit!.

If you are art lover, must visit place. Mostly known for various types of paintings, the surprising drawings are related like "Khajuraho". The quality of paintings are superb and some of the paintings are really ancient and well preserved.

Not the Louvre or the Met. The museum has a respectable collection on view comprised of a representative body of second class works by first class artists. It is interesting to wander about and see the development of these artists.

Free and some excellent works. I haven't yet seen all of it, but the first floor had a wonderful collection of Goya and El Greco as well as other South American works. Lots of Rodin sculptures. You can walk in anytime and take non-flash photos.

Disappointing. We decided to go to this museum knowing full well it could not possibly measure up to the Louvre or the Prado.We did see a few Degas, Toulouse-Lautrec and one Rembrandt worth notice but most if the workd of the grand masters that they have were clearly second rate.It was bgood to see some argentine painters of the early nineteenth century.However, the paintings were mostly poorly lit. I don't mean that they were in lower light used to protect the paintings. I mean some lights were burnt out completely, some cast a reflection that prevented you from seeing them well.On top of that, the staff when asked for help barely answered or just did not care.Since the building is not air conditioned, i am not sure how they expect to protect their paintings.I just did not get a lot of pleasure out if ghis visit and i usually enjoy classical art very much.
Open Museum, closed exhibition. Small and not reach exhibition and half of it closed for renovation for long term.Some important artist but not their central works.
El Greco. We travel the world searching for El Greco. The three paintings were beautifully hung: Jesus in the Garden of Olives, The Tears of St Peter, Christ Carrying the Cross.

Classic art in bite size museum. Lovely to see old masters and local historical art in same building and not so big a building to be indigestable. Special exhibit on history of nudism very well curated.And lovely Rodins
Nice museum. Has some old masters and impressionists, but strongest on Argentine painters. Definitely worth a visit.
Very good choiice. Excelente art museum,important collection most tradicional paintings and sculptures. Concerts on Saturdays, summer and yearly art curses, lectores etc,

Interesting museum. If you like old paintings then this is for you. It wasn't necessarily my thing, but I could appreciate that the art was worth seeing. My favourite part was a temporary photography exhibition on the second floor.

Great Museum Worth Time to Stroll Through. When we were there, floor zero was fully open, and the first floor was being renovated. The second floor contained a temporary photography exhibit. Things are presented in chronological order. The museum is well laid out and presented. Lighting is beautiful.There is no/limited air conditioning, so the interior can be very warm. The day we were there it was in the 80's (at least).There is not as much South American art as we had hoped but what is there is very nice and interesting.If this review is helpful then please indicate so below.

A must see. This museum was the reason for going to Buenos Aires and it didn't disappoint. A beautiful building like a mini Versaille. The rooms are gorgeous and you can't take your time looking at all the exhibits. A great place to spend the afternoon.

Interesting collection. An interesting collection but it is heavy on the Europeans - go to other art galleries, such as the MALBA, for contemporary Argentine painters. Also it is very hot on a warm day. Still worth seeing and it is free entry.

Worth a visit. Popped in and spent a while wandering around and it was a nice relief to get out of the heat. Signage on exhibits in Spanish only. Bit too modern for my liking but good use of space and light and some very different exhibits.

Museum of Fine Arts Buenos Aires. This is a very well laid out fine art museum. Although there are no brochures or signage posted in any language other than Spanish, the art still manages to make itself understood. The floorplan incorporates packaging artists by era or style. There are some good works by many famous artists as well as many of their sketches made while preparing to complete the masterpiece. Admission is free and for some unexplained reason, it was not jam-packed full of visitors on a recent summer Friday afternoon.

Pretty nice.. Clean art museum with a good variety of work, but nothing too great. The except rooms are alright and the quants of works was nothing too great. A good museum for Argentina, but if you have visited museums in Europe you will likely be disappointed.

A wonderful building. What a beautiful building in which to host artworks. The rooms were immaculate with a very good collection of art works to spend an afternoon browsing past. Be prepared to find the odd Caneletto in the most unexpected little corridors. The china, tapestries and furniture are a treat providing a lovely setting for the artworks. The great hall is a magnificent room. Be prepared though to be a little warm - there is no aircon - so huddle before the fans for a bit of cool air before moving on to the next room.
A Little Bit of Everything. This fine museum has works from all of the European masters along with works by many classic Argentinian artists.
Cannot miss.. Exceptional collections of European art as well as Argentian. And it is free entry. You will want at least a few hours.

Rodin exhibit!. It's touted 18th century erotic art was fun, and the El Greco exhibit had only 2 of his paintings, but the extensive Rodin exhibit was wonderful. Their collection of impressionists was really good, including a Van Gough with a realistic rendering which must have been early in his career.
Traditional Encyclopedic Museum focusing on European Art.. If European art is your thing, this is probably one of the best museums in South America displaying such art.
Pleasantly spent time. A wonderful collection of paintings and sculptures. There are, according to the magnificent works. Thank you, the people of Argentina!

Museo Nacional de Bellez arte, Buenos Aires, Argentina – Interesting Special Exhibitions.. I reported last year on this, the most important of BA museums, but wanted to write now again to alert you to a couple of special museum exhibitions that I am sure you would enjoy. The special exhibitions are on till the end of February to the middle of March [see below]. When you plan your visit, please note that the museum will be closed from February 3 till February 13 [inclusive], to complete some unexpected maintenance work. While the purpose is to highlight the special exhibits, no write up on the museum is complete without at least a few words about the permanent collection which is simply excellent. In addition to works by such prominent painters as Manet, Monet, Pissarro, Picasso, Gauguin, Giudici, Van gogh, Gola, Goya, el Greco, modigliani, Sívori, XUL Solar and many others, there are also collections of the work of the famous Argentinean artists Prilidiano Pueyrredón and Antonio Berni. The permanent collection in the third hall, Sala 3, was graciously donated by the descendants of Mr. Alfredo Hirsch and his wife Mrs. Lisa Gottschalk de Hirsch. The art work is primarily European from the 16th and 17th Century. Many items are absolutely fabulous [including a magnificent cabinet]. The collection also includes two portraits of Mr. and Mrs. Hirsch. I always start by visiting Sala 3 and move on to Sala 10, the French art of the XIX century, and Federico Leloir’s “La Toilette de Venus”. Then I find myself drawn to Sala 11, Italian art of the XIX century, and Giacomo Favretto’s “Músicos Ambulantes”, Emilio Gola’s “El Naviglio de Milán” and “I Giusti” by Augusto Ferrari. In Sala 16, the European art of the XIX century there is Jean Jacque Henner’s “Paysanne”. Last, but not least, in Sala 24, the Argentinean art of the XIX century is exhibited among which are two haunting paintings; Ernesto de la Cárcova’s “Sin Pan Y Sin Trabajo” and Reynaldo Giuici’s “La Sopa de los Pobres”. In addition to the permanent collection, the museum will typically have at any time two to three special exhibitions. At this time, the museum has the following three exhibitions that are really worth visiting.The first exhibition is of work by “El Greco” on the occasion of the 400 anniversary of the death of the painter and is very worth seeing. If you prefer, you can also book yourself on a guided visit [guided visits are on from Tuesday to Sunday at 4pm]. The exhibits are found in halls 5, 7, 15 and 21. There is also a short TV program “El Greco – Painter of the invisible” in Sala 7. The treasure of this collection is the “the tears of San Pedro” lent by the museum of Toledo in Spain. The exhibition finishes March 1, 2015.The second exhibition is a collection of art work entitled “The Fatal Seduction – erotic imaginations from the XIX century”. Despite the provocative nature of the topic, the exhibition curator [Laura Malosetti Costa] tastefully put the exhibition together such that at no time did one feel offended. There are over 65 paintings and sculptures in addition to many engravings by European and Argentinean artists. Much of the work was exhibited in this museum and other works were borrowed from other museums in Argentina to complete the exhibition. The works are arranged under different categories such as erotica and violence, nudes, fatal seducers and others; allowing the visitor an overall view of the western erotica. The exhibition is meant to throw a different light on the subject matter and to help the visitor to judge and appreciate the topic in general and the collection in particular. The exhibition finishes March 15, 2015. WELL DONE!! You may also be interested to learn that the general topic of “Amor” is presented in a couple of other museums. In particular the exhibition in the “Casa Nacional Del Bicentinario” [on Riobamba Street] under the name “Enamorar, el amor en movimiento” exhibits and covers all kinds of love. This includes love for God, the country, the family, the party, of food, marriage, reproduction, seduction, erotic love and others. It is actually quite comprehensive. You may want to visit it while the Art Museum is being maintained. Or you can wait for my report on it over the next couple of weeks. The Third exhibition is a collection of pictures entitled “LATINOAMÉRICA, Galería de Imágenes” and donated to the museum by Sara Facio, an Argentine photographer, known for her photographs of various cultural Argentine figures including Argentine writers Julio Cortázar, María Elena Walsh and others. She was born in 1932, and currently lives in San Isidro outside Buenos Aires. This collection of photographs is her collection over the past 50 years. There are 172 pictures some of which are quite interesting. Please do not forget that the museum will be closed till February 13, opening February 14. And that the special exhibitions will end early March as mentioned above. Enjoy!

GREAT GALLERY. We enjoyed walking around this art gallery. It is small so easy to see most of the artwork. Some great French Impressionists and was also interested to tag along and listen to a guide explain a lot about some Argentinian artists as well!

A 3-star collection in a 4-star location. You would never imagine that this museum of strictly classical appearance was remodeled from a former pumping station. You really need to focus only on the ground floor that is quite well laid out and easy to follow with a guide map; nothing useful in English is available. The overall quality of the collection is not that expected of a great city, but it is a cut above what you will see in the provincial cities of major European countries, and covers many periods and styles of European art quite effectively. Best represented are the French Impressionists (some superb Sisleys, Manets and Degas canvasses); Post-impressionists (notably Gauguin and Cezanne); the Spanish School (Zurbaran, Goya and Ribera, but a special exhibition devoted to El Greco included 2 brilliant works in the museum’s own collection); and some impressive sculptures by Rodin (spread over several rooms and not easy to locate) and Bourdelle. There is little of note from the Italian Renaissance, Germany, or Britain ( apart from a Raeburn portrait), and of the great Dutch and Flemish masters, I recall only a single rather dubious painting by Rembrandt and Rubens whose authentication I would worry about. One wing, and a kind of mezzanine ascended by a small staircase, carry a great many Argentinian paintings that I did not find of great interest; merely fashionable and competent, and nowhere near the fresh artistic insights to be seen among the country’s contemporary painters as evident in the MALBA . The furniture and craft works displayed in parallel seemed to me to offer more interest and national identity. Photography and administration take up most of the floor above, so that 90 – 120 minutes should see you through, and one of the attractions is that admission is free.
Beautiful Exhibits!. Did not read about this place before we walked by it, but it was worth an hour or two. Very interesting exhibits for a small-ish art museum, and admission is free (unlike Malba).
Nice museum. Nice museum very close to the Recoletta Cemetery. The features are several paintings and sculptures by world famous artists. Don't miss the photography exhibit on the top floor.

Must-visit Latin-American museum. S34°35.051' W58°23.602' many billionaires achieve immortality buying great art and donating it to their premier museum. Look for the donation signs. This museum knows its attractions and offers a non-English shortcut map to its masterpieces. That alone makes visiting this museum mandatory for art buffs. Dutch and Flemish masters, like Rembrandt and his students, Rubbens, Frans Hals, and modern painters like Pissarro, Van Gogh (earlier work), Sisley, Monet, Toulouse Lautrec, Degas, Renoir, and Gauguin are on display. Opposing European masters, the museum displays many Latin-American artists. Paintings of Angel Della Valle, like the La vuelta del malón from 1892 stood out for us in January 2015. Mastering the Spanish language is necessary because the museum provides almost no English translation. The photography on the second level is interesting.

Nice museum in Recoleta, free entrance. The museum has a good collection of classical paintings from Europe and Latin America. Explanations are only in Spanish.We especially liked the photo exhibit on the top floor (hard to find, but there is a small elevator).
Some truly awful paintings. I really didn't like this place almost at all. Glad it was free as I didn't stay. Probably a matter of taste.
Classic in every way. So many fun things to do. This is a must do!! We go back every time we are in BsAs!!!! Easy location and access...

A great museum in a great city. The number of art works, the quality of the paintings, the arrangement of the different areas of the museum give Buenos Aires the feeling of a city that cares about the impression it causes the visitors. And to encourage people to visit, entrance it is free of charge.

Awesome Collection -- must see.. Really great collection of a lot amazing artists. I can honestly say I was surprised. There was one floor that was in construction, but I still enjoyed my time. On the top floor there was a photography exhibit which was a lovely addition to the paintings.One thing to note, everything is in Spanish. It wasn't an issue for me since I speak Spanish -- but I think that those who only speak English should be aware -- but I do think that going just to take in the paintings is worthwhile. There are tours given in English that are done on certain days, I would make sure to look on the website and make sure to go during that time if knowing the history of the painting and the artists would be important to you.

wonderful, quiet, impressive. You will find old maestros from Latin America and Europe. The pictures are presented very well and the whole atmosphere in this museum is calm and intense. If you do not have a lot of time in Buenos Aires, you will reach the place also with the hop on - hop off - bus.

What a collection!. The collection here would be an asset to any major city. Starting with medieval art (of which there are several rooms), through some fantastic baroque pieces and a wide number of 19c French and impressionist paintings, we were blown away by both the quality and the scale of the holdings here. Also of great interest are some of the decorative arts (the combs with high headdresses to be worn with mantillas are amazing, as are the netsukes). Don't miss some of the Argentine art of the 19c. Well worth the visit.

Quality Art. An unbelievable collection. I never imagined that a National Museum would have such an impressive collection. Free for anyone to visit it is a must go to Museum. Centrally located in the Recoleta area you can see works of art from great masters such as Goya, Zubaran, Cesanne, Coubert, Van Gogh, El Greco, Manet, Rembrandt, Kandinsky, Pollock just to name a few.

Very Impressive Collection. I did not know what to expect from this museum and was quite favorably impressed. The collection is compact, but is very good, with some beautiful impressionist paintings. The El Greco's are well worth the view as well. If you are looking at the traditional art scene, this is the collection to view.
A Nice History Lesson. We enjoyed the paintings depicting some of the history of Argentina, and an art student gave an excellent free guided tour. The collection has good variety.

Worth a visit. This is a great little art gallery. Quite a nice collection - Argentine artists and international ones. Not very big compared to some other cities, but if you're in the Recoleta barrio, or need something to do to get out of the heat or the rain, it's worth an hour or so.

I want to go back. Impressive collection of very interesting pieces. Read the descriptions next to the paintings! They have critic reviews from the era that describe the sentiment of the art at the time.
Quality Over Quantity. A small but very nice gallery containing several old masters. It is also free which is nice. Go give it an hour of your time.
Good art museum. this art museum was actually really good. I have been to quite a few in South America and the collection here is interesting, different, and well organized. Definitely worth a visit!

Eh, if you have time. After seeing MALBA, this museum was just so-so. The layout is odd - all the rooms are different bold colors, which affects the art hanging on the walls. Also, most of the museum is warm and humid, which seems odd since they'd want to preserve the works. Lastly, the art that is there simply isn't that interesting. Sure there are some Monets, Degas, and Manets, but otherwise it's just a fairly bland museum. If you have to choose, choose MALBA.
Free admission. Some really amazing pieces in the collection. The Degas works are a standout, especially the ballerina in pastel.Well worth a visit.

A small collection with some real highlights. Two or three rooms of Impressionist and post Impressionist paintings provided real pleasure. Some of the Argentine paintings (all completely unknown to this European) were also most interesting.

We were lucky. to be there on a day when they have a free 45 minutes tour of the highlight of the museum.We were surprised by some of the famous painters represented in the museum.They refuse to loan them on tour, afraid that they will be confiscated by countries which Argentina owes money.I would recommend taking the tour (Tue & Thu.)

Very nice. A lovely small collection, that had a Goya show up during our visit, a interesting overview of Argentine artists, some wonderful Impressionists, etc. A mix of displaying styles - some better than others. And I believe it is free!

A diverse and lovely collection. One of the most beautiful Van Gogh paintings I've ever seen; a fine and amusing miniature collection; the private collection of a gentleman displayed as it had been in his home; Argentinian painters telling the history of the country. Could only wish for more choices in the bookstore/gift shop.

Good place to spend a couple of hours. Surprisingly good, if not extensive, collection of old masters including Rodin, Gauguin, Goya, Sisley, Manet, El Greco and Degas in an imposing building. There is also an impressive Argentine and Latin American art section. And it's free!

worth a see, its free. Just went to MALBA, nearly missed this, glad I went though as it's very close and free.Was disappointed that there is so much European art here, a lot of which didn't really interest me. Loved the rooms with the impressionist paintings. Some of the other galleries seem very crowded, with so many paintings on the walls it feels a bit like a flee market. Had some interesting Argentinian artists paintings at the end. You can do the gallery fairly quickly, depending on whay you like. We only spent about 45 minutes here. Worth a visit if you have time.
Museum of Art. Great paintings and special exhibits. Free. But nothing in English except a very nice student-led English 1-hour tour.

Impressive collection of European and Argentinian masterpieces. There is a nice collection of 15th and 16th century art from Italy and central Europe, as well as a truly impressive collection of 19th and early 20th century European artists. The collection of Argentinian artists on display are also quite nice.The museum is not too large, but do make sure to take the time to find the new exhibits on display.

Top rated art museum. A real surprise for art lovers. Excellent and well displayed pieces from just about every period of art history. There was also a new wing with a current almost amusing exhibit devoted to erotic art.

Number one museum in B.A.. Not to be missed. It houses some international art work from different periods and all of the local artists that change from time to time as the space is not enough for all of them at the same time. Merits a couple of hours.

The finest collection in BA. This is the most important museum in BA. Local and classic artists'works are exhibited here. It's free and you may relax having a coffee in its cafeteria enjoying the view on to the Public Law School.
Buenos Aires Bellas Artes museum. Excellent collection of paintings and sculptures from European and some local artists. Centrally located.Worth a visit.

Boring. The museum is housed in a converted water works. Not overly inviting. It also has very strange opening hours. Given this is the major art gallery the contents are generally not too great with few pictures of any note. We were in and out in less than 30 minutes and had seen all the galleries ! Would suggest if you have limited time that you go to the Museum of Latin Art - a more rewarding experience

Small but interesting museum. One to two hours is more than enough for visiting this Museum the visit can easily combined with Recoleta vist The Museum contains a mix of local artist and international artists (Rembrandt, Monte , Dega and a room full with El Greco).Its hard to compare this museum to the big museum in NYC or Paris but still worse-while the visit,Admission is free.
Good art. A free museum full of surprisingly good pieces of European and Argentinean art. Well Worth a visit, also for its attractive location
Excellent. Excellent gallery with many well known artists on display. Very well presented - If you are visiting BA don't miss it

Museo Nacional de Bellas Artes. On entering the Museo we were given a guide that indicated some significant art works. We were delighted to find that this guide was merely the tip of the iceberg of significant art in this gallery. The collection is huge. As we wandered through the exhibition halls we found scuptures by Rodin, a whole room full of Goya's, works by Sorolla, Pissarro, Gauguin and many more artists who were familiar to us as well as Latin American artists who we were not familiar with. Apart from sculpture and painting there is a great collection of silver. It is a wonderful gallery and it is free.

Get the free guided tour!. I was very impressed by the art expositions and that there is no admission fee for the museum. It was a pitty we just missed the temporary exposition of Sorolla, one of my favourite painters from the city Valencia where I work as a cityguide.But we did see great other European art, also there was an expo about El Greco We where the only ones that signed up for the free guided tour, and our guide was great! Since we know a bit more about European art the guide told us he would take us to the Argentinian artworks. He explained and made the paintings come alive for us. Really a must see!
Don't miss if you like art. Free to visit and you can store the things you are carrying for free as well.If you like art you really can't miss it.

Big variety in a sweet little museum. This museum's collection is excellent and eclectic. Small enough so that a few hours here feels complete. The day we went it was free--there are some lovely impressionist paintings (Monet et al), a significant collection of El Greco and Goya, a lively collection of bronzes. Two wonderful Pizzaros, just bursting with sunlight. Near La Biela, a wonderful spot to chill out with coffee and medialunas.

Very traditional art museum. If you like to go through a traditional art museum, with lots of European artwork from past centuries, this is for you. It is rather staid and predictable. The day we visited only one of the two floors was open, and we breezed through in one hour and felt we could have better spent our time somewhere else.

Impressive building. This is worth a look. The European art is not not top notch even though a number of noteworthy artists are represented. It's hard to judge the quality of the Argentine art but it was interesting to view. The building is impressive and easy to navigate.

Worth a visit. Currently only the first floor is open for visits. The remainder is undergoing a renovation. Still worth stopping by. Excellent English language tours are available at 1 Pm on Friday & either Tuesday or Wednesday. No fee.

Some interesting pieces of art. The layout isn't the easiest to follow but once you have found your bearings there are some good pieces of European modern art on view although I should stress that I'm not saying that Argentinian art is not worth a viewing. A real positive is that is free to enter.

Disappointing collection. I have visited many fine art museums across the States and Europe, and I have to say that I found the collection of moderate size and completely underwhelming. I did not expect the impressionist section to be great but I did expect that the section devoted to Argentine artists to shine. It did not. There are many better things to see in Buenos Aires,

Interesting but Peculiar. the MNBA isn't very large and doesn't take a long time to view. Our opinion is that the Argentinian artists are the most interesting pieces though there is a big El Greco exhibit that is pretty special. Much of the museum is arrange by donor, so all the pieces that were donated by a single individual or family are together and that is a little odd as the works tend to be all over the map in terms of style, artist, era. There is one VanGogh that would have made the trip worthwhile. I've never seen it or any like it before.

Beautiful. It's free and there's hundreds of great artists' originals. I had to go there 3 afternoons to fully appreciate everything. Besides, there's lots of landmarks and interesting places around. A must-see, even for a quick visit if you're not much of an art person.

Bellas Arte. A nice place to visit. noting common with moma, but some nice artwork to enjoy in the greeny place of bsAs.
Worth a walk when the weather is fine

The collection was amazing.. Even if the building where the museum is located isn't that great, the collection is really amazing so it doesn't matter if the building isn't beautiful compared to other buildings in Buenos Aires. Really great.

What an amazing collection - and FREE!. We braved the pouring rain to walk three blocks from our rental apartment to the Museo Nacional de Bellas Artes in Buenos Aires. What a treat! From the gorgeous traveling exhibit of original sculptures by Rodin (including, much to our surprise, his world-famous "The Kiss"), to an eclectic and prodigious formerly-private-collection of European, Argentinian and Chinese pieces (look for the photos of the art as it originally was displayed in the family's home), to more recent Argentine art, this museum kept the attention of our party of five (three adults and two kids ages) for over two hours.Despite the rain, or perhaps because of it, the museum was mostly empty. We were able to see known-and-lesser-known works by some of the impressionist masters without having to jostle elbows with other visitors. Our 15 year old daughter was thrilled with the room dedicated to Degas, and our 11 year old son spent a good amount of time peering in to the almost-side-scroll-comic-book-like military history paintings by Argentine artist Candido Lopez.The second floor happened to be closed today (maybe all of this month?), so we found that the museum was just the right size. Weekend non-winter hours are 9:30 AM to 8:30 PM. It's free of charge. There's an English language tour on Tuesdays at 1 PM.

Very good museum. Very good museum even for people not so interesting into art or paintings. The chinese collection was impressive. It is near the Recoleta and Evita monuments so you can spend a few moments there, especially if it is very hot outside. Furthermore, it is free so do not miss a chance to take a look around.

excellent museum !. they have unique pieces of art and the most wonderful collection of Argentine and South American art . This museum is very big so better decide before you start the visit what is it that you don't want to miss .

loved it!. I went in Oct 2014, and was able to see the incredible collection of classical art, and an exhibit dedicated to Julio Cortasar. Great museum, free entrance, not too huge and very logical layout (cannot get lost or tired of walking like in many large museums). I highly recommend to visit it, and it stays open until 7pm, which is great. There is a lot to do in Rocoleta area around the museum.
Average!. If you have been to Europe and visited many museums and galleries there, then you may want to give this one a miss. The major part is a collection of European arts.

My Favorite Art Museum in Buenos Aires. A visit to Buenos Aires for any art lover would not be complete without experiencing this art gallery. A former native of London, UK, I have lived in Buenos Aires for more than a year and travelled to major cities throughout the world, and this gallery compares with the best.The collection of art here is mind blowing. French Impressionism, modern art, Rodin and other sculptures, south american art and more.There are also ever changing exhibitions on the top floor. I visit regularly and always take visitors here. Did I mention that all this if FREE?? www.mnba.gob.ar/

Had my doubts.... I had my doubts about this museum.... it looked rather down at the heels, and the color is gross. But once inside, there was some really wonderful stuff, although the rundown air lingered. Too bad Argentina cannot get its economic act together.

Notable, classic pieces & interesting S American tastes. Enjoyed visiting and viewed the entire collection. Not an enormous museum, so it is comfortable to do it in an hour. Nice Rodin sculptures and a variety of classical styles are displayed. You can check your coats, umbrella and items at the entrance so that you won't need to carry them with you.
Excellent museum!. Really nice museum with a wonderful assortment of European and Latin America art; paintings and sculptures of all sorts, with lots of "name" artists.

The right size for an art gallery.. This gallery is just the right size; get hold of the highlights brochure and work your way around them all; it takes about an hour and is time very well spent as they have some gems here.

Very nice collection in a friendly setting. I really enjoyed this museum. The collection is not huge but it has a lot of very interesting things. Be attentive to side rooms... they have little jewels. Do not miss the Degas and Manet paintings! I also like the unusual Van Gogh. I do not remember seeing a restaurant and handicapped access may not be available. I loved the noise and the comments of people watching the art. The museum opens at 12:30 and it is free. I say it takes about 90 minutes to take a good look at the collection. There is a short walk to la Recoleta where you can have a nice lunch after seeing this beautiful museum. I forgot to mention that some of the rooms have a very outdated layout and some nice artists work may be difficult to find without the aid of the charts.
The best free beautiful arts museum. Not only its collection includes some of the greatest names (El Greco, Rembrandt, Manet, Rodin, Degas, Gauguin, Goya) but also it's free. Don't miss it!

Great Art Museum. Here you will find a beautifully arranged art collection. Pieces by Monet, Manet, Degas, Rodin, and others. It is free and you can take photos or video if you like. It is great for a nice little short visit.

Museum Small to visit. It is free so makes it worth the visit There are mainly are a few small collections of the impressionist artist Monet, Degas and Manet. Some larger collections by Argentina Benefactors and some very nice Buenos Aries Artist over 1 floor.

beautiful Museum. Great option to go on a weekend.- during the week its closed by 8pm. - Its free of charge, and displays a great collection of both local and international artists. its located on a safe area you can walk to .

Enough to make it interesting. Was disappointed in so much of BA - had been years since my last trip and apart from the normal Recoleta, La Boca , Palermo etc. was wondering what to do. This may not be Europe at its best, but still worthwhile as there are many works of interest.

Nice museum. It's a nice well maintained museum.Has pieces of art of various themes and it's free.It's really close to Floralis Generica, so it could be an option to visit both, since a walk in this museum can easily be done in a few hours or less.NOTE: currently it is closed on mondays - check their website.

Good free museum. Great because its free and there are many interesting works of artDont expect it to be in the Met or Louvre category though easy to traverse and small comparitivlyAlso make sure its open

The Where's Waldo experience of finding the Latin American Art. We went to this museum for one simple reason: it was the only one open early (that's Argentina early - so 10 or 10:30.) Beautiful collection of European classics, very impressive. But it's the top floor that holds the surprise. Tucked away, almost hidden, are amazing works by Latin American artists. Works with energy and passion and politics and rage and love. They were the most moving works we saw, but it was almost as though the museum wanted them secreted away so the focus would be on the (justifiably) impressive European works. Don't miss the top floor. It's the best part.

Wonderful free museum with quality art. Museum curators feel all art should be free to view. Hear, hear! Great stuff from baroque all the way to impressionist with a great helping of Argentinean artists who in addition to being technically accomplished, exhibit such raw emotion in their work. Check out "no bread, no job" for a real kick in the gut.Goya, Van Gogh, Manet, etc etc well represented. Several groups of very well behaved and attentive elementary school kids and their teachers. Never happen in many parts of the states because of the (gasp!) nudes.Great stuff

Nothing special. If you've been to the great art museums of the USA and Europe, then after reading the reviews billing this as the best art museum in S. America you will be somewhat disappointed. Its perfectly pleasant, but its certainly not in the premier league of art museums. Disappointingly, despite advertising it on their website, they did not have any audio tours. Also note currently only the ground floor is open. I found the small amount of Argentinian art very impressive, but this only made up a tiny fraction of the museum. Its also disappointing they don't have much english information - specially given the extremely detailed articles about some of the pictures on the website. Would be nice to be able to read this whilst in the museum (downloading it would be a rather expensive option on a european phone)
Peaceful gallery. Very lovely and peaceful gallery with some pretty famous pieces. A nice tag-on to a trip to Recoleta Cemetary as it´s just around the corner.

Great Free Museum. It is a great museum! You don't expect it to hold so many valuable pieces from argentine to very known famous artists (Van Gogh)! We joined a Free tour by the museum an english girl(Anna). She made the tour simply amazing, she explained everything in detail, easy to understand and pointed out things that we will never think of (argentine wars and crisis)! We where so happy that we tried to tip her, but we didn't had any cash with us at the moment! Sorry Anna! So if you can just drop her an extra pesos in our behalf! Cheers,

Perfect for student-travellers!. I loved this museum, and not only for the fact that there's no entrance fee, but also because it includes so many different artists and so much information about the history of latin art. I'd highly recommend this museum for people who don't just want to look at art but learn about it as well.Visited August 2013

Good Art Museum Made Better Because Its Free. This museum was well-hyped in TripAdvisor and all of the other guides at which we looked. Quite frankly, while this was a good museum, it was significantly less impressive than some of the recent museums I have visited such as the ones in Detroit and Chicago. However, this is still quite a nice place and the fact that it was free made it a worthwhile stop.The paintings were fairly limited as they were mostly European impressionist works. But there were several renowned artists represented such as Manet, Degas, Van Gogh and others. There were some lovely decorative arts on display as well and a small room on the upper level dedicated to graphic arts. I was especially intrigued with the display of local artists, many of which were quite good. This display of Argentinian artists was of particular note because it was something unlikely to be seen anywhere else.Overall, my assessment was that this was a very good museum and is definitely worth visiting if you are an art aficionado. But I don't think it lived up to the ceremonious build-up I saw, especially in the quantity and variety of works on display. If you are just a casual art fan, it might not be worth going out of the way. Still, I thought it was a pleasant two or three hours of browsing. It's worth noting that the building itself was also impressive and one might appreciate the architecture as much as the art work inside.
one sunny afternoon. Brilliant day's exploring this fantastic gallery...unfortunately I missed the Caravaggio but the latin art history and collections were amazing!

A very impressive art museum. Free admission and you can spend hours walking through the various rooms housing work from some of the most famous artists in history. Most of the information is written in Spanish, some in English, and they also offer English speaking tours twice a week. Would highly recommend!

loved this museo. I loved this museo it provides you with excellent art information and for an experienced traveler it´s key to learn all the advantages and disadvantages of art and its people. Overall, great!
Beautiful Art for Free. This was a beautiful museum available to all for free. The rooms were a little too dimly lit but overall, the experience was great!
Free and worth a visit. Free! You won't be able to take your eyes off of the painting of Rembrandt's sister! Worth a visit for sure.

Incredible collection. This museum has the most incredible art collection, from grand masters through to modern photography. It's very easy to stroll through, & easy to find individual artworks, & best of all- it's free entry!
Small museum , nice collection. This is a sweet museum with a nice collection of mostly European Art. The museum store is a bookstore with a good assortment if art books in Spanish.
Worth a Visit. Really nice gallery with some good pieces. Rodin collection is worth seeing. Not too big so easy to see everything in a short period of time. Would highly recommend

Impressive Collection. Went to the Bellas Artes and were very impressed that such an extensive collection does not charge an entry fee. The museum is spacious, well laid out and has a wealth of brilliant paintings. Well worth an hour or two.
Beautiful. I enjoyed the artwork and a wide variety of artists. It also helps that there is no entrance fee! A must in BsAs.

A first class museum. The first time I went to the museum, I didn't have many expectations, but once I was inside, I saw it was a first class art museum, with lot of national and international works of art.

Museo Nacional de Bellas Artes, arte argentino.. I spend a month once a year in Buenos Aires and I always visit the Museum of fine Arts, to greet once more my favourite pictures. International visitors should not expect to find the utmost expressions of Impressionism in this Museum or in any other in Latin America, the best Impressionists are at the Quai d'Orsay, and the most famous museums in Europe and the States. The small Impressionists collection owned by the Museo de Bellas Artes is a bequest from the Santamarinas, argentinian collectors. As private collectors they didn't possess the most famous specimens. It's more convenient to see the argentinian painters and the temporary exhibitions. Last time I went there was one from Pio Collivadino, he was the first "urban painter" in the country, it is very moving to see the way he has depicted poor neighbourhoods and poor people. There is no fee for this attraction but it would be nice to buy some Bonos Contribución. There is an elevator but when I was there it didn't work (it might happen), anyway, the Museum has only two levels.

Nice international collection with limited Argentinian works. This museum houses a nice international collection with works by Rubens, Van Gogh, Rodin, Goya, Rembrandt, Monet and others. The collection of works by Argentinian painters was, based on my expectations, very limited - I was definitely hoping for more and was a bit disappointed in the relatively small collection. I have many opportunities to see the great European painters and was looking forward to the Argentinian works. Do manage your expectations if you visit. It is a lovely museum and the works are well displayed. Additionally, and much appreciated, there is a great deal of information about the history of the museum and the collections.

Not to be missed. We found this museum to be a better experience than MALBA. It is free, it has a wonderful collection, especially of European masters, but we mostly appreciated the art of Argentina found here. We learned a lot of history from the wing dedicated to Argentinian art. There are many special pieces here, and wonderful collections. They also had a wonderful temporary exhibit of photographs. This is well worth at least two hours for the visit.

Worth a visit. A good selection of local art as well as 19th century European post-impressionalist works including Manet. The last Thursday night of the month they open at night with live music in the galleries and free beer on the roof.
A great collection. Entrance is free, so there's no reason not to go. There's some great works, including a van Gogh and several Rodins.

Outstanding Fine Arts Museum. The National Museum of Fine Arts is the best of its kind in South America and is a national treasure. The collection spans several centuries of European and Argentinian art. The focus is on 19th century Europe and contemporary Argentina. The ground floor has 24 exhibition halls featuring artists such as Rodin, Rembrandt, El Greco, Goya (an entire room), and many late 19th century artists--Manet, Sorolla, Monet, Van Gogh, Gauguin and Degas. Admission is free. Temporary exhibitions are featured. A gift shop is available. The Museum is a short walk from the Decorative Arts museum, reviewed separately.

Cannot miss the English tour from Anna!. We swung by here not knowing what to expect... but were just in time for english tour from Anna Lowe. It quickly became the highlight of our trip! There as a ton of European works... an early Van Gogh was a highlight for us.The Museum is currently under repair and most of the local art wasn't able to be viewed. It gives us a reason to go back next time we are in town :)

Notable Artists. Overall excellent. Compact. One hour plenty of time. Opened at 12:30 that day. In good area of town and easy to find with Google Maps. University of Buenos Aires across street has some art in lobby too. Free. Bag check at door. Mainly French and Italian paintings with some other nationalities and art types too. Monet, Renoir, Pissarro, Gogan, etc. Not comparable to art galleries in France, Italy, Spain, etc. but free and well done. Renovation ongoing.

Excelent and free. Do you want to see beautiful art pieces, like in Louvre and London Museum, but you don't want to spend a single dolar on it? (of course is much smaller than those famous museums)The MNBA is free well ambiented and has a very nice variety of paintings, sculptures and other art pieces.It is only 2 blocks from Recoleta area.Enjoy!

The classics plus local flavor. Worth a visit to see some works by local artists. Also the typical array of European art, but you can see that in Europe. Our BA friend explained the significance of the battle scenes, which helped our appreciation.

very nice and free. this is a very nice art museum. and free. there are a few outstanding things there. a van gogh i have never seen before and a wonderful degas pastel. and some nice rodin sculptures. and when you are done, there you are in recoleta. many wonderful places to have lunch.
Great Museum for free.. This museum holds lots of important works by artists from the whole world and it is completely free. Our problem was that we did not have enough time to visit it..

I fear for the art here. This tiny museum touts itself as the best art collection in South America. Hm. It has a little of everything in the European genres, but mostly second and third tier. All of it is just fine except that the museum isn't air conditioned. On a reasonably nice day in April, the place was stifling and I worry that the art is going to suffer over time. They have one room of ancient art which is air conditioned and closed off with glass doors so they know that temperature is a factor. Why they leave the other art to the elements I can't understand. Well worth seeing are the fabulous Argentinian ladies' hair combs, many tortoise shell and some the size of peacock tails.

Enjoyed our visit. We didn't expect to see the variety of work on display at this museum. From the greats of Europe to local works, oils to sculptures, spanning the centuries, we enjoyed our visit. The second floor is under reconstruction, the third had a great display of cartoon art we also enjoyed. A great and rewarding afternoon.

Classic art in richly hued rooms. The saturated hues in the salons (deep turquoise, rich oxblood red) feels like a warm embrace surrounding these works of art. Nicely curated, there is a great variety of sculpture, tapestries and paintings- AND it's free!
surprising French impressionist master pieces. We mostly liked the French impressionist school (Gaugin, Manet, Renoir) but we also saw local artists of very high quality
Excellent!. This museum is fantastic!, beautiful and modern. Free admission, and very good art. From french art to argentinian art.

Beautiful building with a limited but comprehensive collection!. Impressive building with a lovely collection of classical, impressionistic and Latin art. A bit warm inside - it was a rainy day when we visited - so the temperature controlled special collections room was a welcome relief. Favorite? Rodin's "The Kiss."

One of the best museums& collections!. loved this museum! wow! as a fine art major, i was in heaven. lots of french impressionists - all from private collections. Very high quality art and a beautiful musuem
A landmark in Recoleta. A very good collection o classic and modern painting and sculpture, from Degas to Gauguin to Renoir to Picasso to Rodin: And also great Argentine artists!

Fine art, poor climate control. Nice selection of fine European and argentine art, but the humidity in the building must have been close to 80% and Temps in the 80f range. I don't know how they plan to maintain these 400 year old paintings but don't let that detract you from what is otherwise a very nice museum with free admission.
Worth a visit. This gallery is definitely worth a few hours. It could be good to do on a rainy day. Never really crowded and overall a pleasant experience.

A world class museum. This is a classic museum with a wonderful collection. Spend an afternoon wandering the colorful galleries to look at the classics including Gauguin and Goya, then head to the modern wing for a special photography exhibition. I especially loved the way the museum displayed the collection is richly colored rooms.

A bit of everything. I really loved the variety of works on display, from Latin American artists to French Impressionists. They have a lovely collection which is worth spending an hour or two visiting. I do wish though that they would light the paintings better. You have to view them from the side because of the glare.

easy viewing; some nice exhibits. Nice section of Buenos Aires. I think it was free. They had some nice paintings and sculptures. Not the Louvre (Thank goodness) but a fun 2 hours - casual and uncrowded.
Enjoyable. I love the arts from other countries and totally enjoyed this museum. Huge collection of world renown painters. The space was quiet and relaxing.

Well worth a visit. If you enjoy works of art, and are not expecting the creme de la creme of world art, this free to enter museum has a very interesting and enjoyable collection of European and South American art. I wouldn't have missed it.

Skip this underwhelming museum. Although the museum is free, I don't think it is worth the time. Most of the pieces in the museum are European and many are from obscure artists. There are only a couple of rooms with art from Argentina and the rest of Latin America.
Good collection. Admission is free, and staff are helpful. Very good collections of impressionist art and artists from South America. Definitely worth a visit.

Fine art with an Argentinian accent. This museum was supposed to make the people of BA classier, by exposing them to the Old Masters. They're here, along with a nice collection of Impressionists to round out your visit. If you're interested in contemporary works, you might find some in the annex or on the top floor, but MALBA has a better selection of these, and not too far away. It's not an overwhelming museum experience, like you'll find in New York, LA, or many of the European capitols, but Bellas Artes is a pleasant place to see some interesting works.

Surprisingly Broad Collection. Fabulous and free museum with a great collection of paintings and sculpture. Highly recommended - and you only need a couple of hours to see the current and permanent displays.

A Nice Collection to Visit for Free. I was amazed to learn that this nice museum, the MNBA as it is known, or in English National Museum of Fine Arts, was FREE to visit. What a deal. Where else can you see Rodins, Manets, Monets, Renoirs, van Gogh, Degas, Gauguin and others for this price. Granted that you won't see these artist's most impressive work, but it is so fun to see lesser known paintings. There was also a large number of Argentine artists with impressive works. There are 24 galleries to wander through, and not too many people. It was a good 2 hours well spent. If there was an admission charge, this collection would be worth 4 stars, but being free to visit bumped this into the 5 star category.

Interesting. A rather small building, parts were under renovation. We were looking for art by local artists. The major exhibit was a collection of photos of mothers and grandmothers of "The Missing." Interesting, but not quite what we had in mind.
Beautiful collection. The Museum has a myriad of great international and regional art. Never crowded so you are able to view at length without being disturbed.

Easy museum to navigate. The museum is a very manageable size, and the art is displayed beautifully. I went to see the Rodins, Manets, and Renoirs, but I ended up spending more time learning about the great Spanish and South American artists. There is a really good Sorolla painting.

Good holdings. There were some very interesting art works which also included some Argentine artists.
There was no fee to get in which was a nice surprise!
Lovely museum, worth the visit. Not huge, but beautifully laid out with plenty of great paintings and sculpture. Easy cab or bus ride in the spacious green area near Recoleta and Palermo.
Surprisingly Excellent. Well worth the visit. A very interesting collection and a good display. The museums past curators and donors dererve our thanks

I love Manuelita Rosas. A very good sample of old and new argentinian beaux arts, the picture of Manuelita Rosas is an utmost expression of XIX century painting, so as the naïve depiction of the Paraguay war of Cándido López. There are some Rodin pieces, namely a copy of Le Baiser that was donated to the Museum by Rodin himself.

A stunning array of painting - on the ground floor. This gallery is FREE to enter and has long opening hours too. I have been to this gallery today (Feb 27th) and the ground floor is given over the a large amount of different styles of paintings throughout the centuries and there are ones by Sisley, Monet, Lautrec, van Gogh, Renoir, Pissarro, Manet and Degas ........ and no doubt I will have missed many more famous names! The first floor is currently closed and the second floor is very small and currently has a lot of portrait photographs of old ladies, firstly without head scarves on and then the same ladies WITH headscarves on - most odd! The views from the outside balcony of the second floor though are quite good. Depending on how much you like art will dictate how long you spend here. A few hours can easily be passed. Shame about the horrid exterior colour of the building.

Love this museum. We enjoyed the art and the exhibits here - quite small in comparison to other national museums in other countries, but items beautifully displayed in each room. A must see when visiting Buenos Aires even during sunny days.

Finding an unknown artist. The museum has a fair collection of old art—my husband was taken with the impressionist room, I thought most of the pieces were fine art but not the top of the line from the artists. However around a corner and up some stairs we ended up in a show about an Argentine artist, Larrañaga, who lived from about 1900 to the 1960s. He studied in Spain and did some fascinating work in Spain and later in Argentina A rather pleasant way to spend an hour seeing very good pieces from an artist we had never heard of. He was in disfavor after Perón was kicked out in a coup in the 1950s but obviously in on the way back up in the hearts and minds of the Argentines.

Expected better. The gallery was disappointing in several ways. The art, for the most part, except for European masters, was not interesting. The building itself is not comfortable as some rooms are air-conditioned and others not. The Rothchild gallery is the most interesting one in the museum.

Reflects the C19th taste for all things French. The permanent collection is housed in 18 small rooms on the ground floor. It has a provincial feel to it but with one or two pleasant surprises including a work by Berthe Morisot and a small well executed painting by Renoir. Much of the rest is inferior with several works by Degas and a large sketch by Manet in an elaborate frame. In addition to C19th French art there are also some C17th Flemish works.

Now with free English tours!. I really like this museum. It has a great collection of European and Argentinian art and is well worth a visit. Only thing that always bothered me was the lack of english info, but i went in today and they started doing a very good free english tour! It's on tuesday, thursday and friday at 12:30 and saturday at 14:00. Made the museum a lot more accessible!

Surprisingly very rich. Excellent display and very rich collection of the European 19th century for a country of the new world...Good collection of American painters unfortunately unknown in Europe.Very impressive exhibition of the Hirsch private collection presented like in a house as it certainly used to be.The musuem was under refurbishment during our visit and we sow only the ground gfloor but it is worth the visit

Small but good rotating contemporary exhibits. This museum has a standing collection of French impressionists and rotating exhibits. I am mostly interested in contemporary art, so I just skimmed the main exhibits, then saw a great photography show featuring close ups of the Madres de la Plaza de Mayo, the women who protested against the disappearance of their children during the dictatorship. Worth a trip.

Very good museum - worth the trip. The museum is quite impressive - especially the collection of Argentine art, and also the collection of indigenous art and articles. Also, the building is beautiful, and we've spent may pleasant hours here. Worth a special trip.
Incredibly wide collection. A huge museum, the building itself is great. Has a really wide range of paintings to see. Worth a visit

Worth a visit. This is definitely worth spending an hour looking at the Argentian art. The other classics are not special but worth a quick visit. For some rason security was very tight on the day we visited and there seemed more janitors than visitors which wad very intimidating. I really wish they could do decent English translations of the brochures - try understanding the first paragraph of the official 'plan'!
Excellent collection. Very good collection of Western European and Latin American art. We also saw an excellent photographic exhibit based on the Abuelas de la Plaza de Mayo movement.

No A/C and half of it is closed.. My husband and I spent a few hours here. That was all we could take in 30 C heat with high humidity and no A/C. The permanent collection has some good pieces, but they are sadly neglected and in desperate need of restoration. This whole museum should be a showpiece but it is rundown and I came away feeling sad. the washrooms are even old and shabby.There are 2 floors, and the upper floor was closed.
