There is a small exhibit space up on the roof, with hardly anything there.They are very proud in their literature of the fact that it is free, and so all the people could attend, but they would be better advised to charge a small fee and take better care of their paintings!

Do not miss it!!!. You will find beautiful Argentinian and International old Paintings like a Van Gogh, a Monet, very known Argentinian classic paintings, and more...
The curator s staff did a great job!!! Congratulations!!!
worth the visit!. Lots of beautiful old paintings, including a Van Gogh, a Monet, and many more, and some interesting artifacts! Take your Spanish dictionary if you are not fluent.

Most Impressive. The exterior of this nondescript building belies the scale and grandeur inside. Original works by the greatest masters of all time are displayed in magnificent and well maintained halls. Congratulations to the curator and his staff

Dark and incoherent. The museum is dark and not well curated. It's what you imagine a boring museum to be -- hard to understand, no map or guide to what you're looking at, and outdated space. The museum did not adhere to the opening hours on its web site the day I visited. If you're sure you want to see some of the pieces here, then visit; otherwise, spend your time at MALBA or sitting outside at a parilla.

Don't expect to be stunned. If you have already visited the Louvres in Paris, or the Hermitage in St Petersburg, well, what can you say. It's a nice small museum, but nothing impressive. There are a couple of paintings that caught my attention, but nothing memorable. Visited on a Sunday, I was not in a rush, but 15 minutes later, I was out of the door. I felt a bit sorry for all the security staff sitting in there the whole day. But please, don't let my words discourage your visit. It's worth it if you have the time.

Enjoy Art for Free. Showcasing Argentinian and European fine art, this was a great way to spend a rainy afternoon in Buenos Aires. I enjoyed the bold wall colors of the galleries and the art placement. The museum has a nice collection of European impressionist and renaissance painters, and several rooms dedicated to Argentinian artists It is free and small enough to be explored in a few hours.

Potential, but Disappointing. First off, it's free. The first floor has a number of pieces by recognized masters. No information in any language other than Spanish and Portuguese. No audio phones. Two exhibits closed.

No Information in English!. I did not enjoy this musuem at all and the main reason was because they did not provide any information about the various pieces of art in English. Also the works by the well known artists were not impressive at all! However entry to this museum was free so i guess that I should not have expected much.
Nice Museum. This is a nice museum close to the parks and Recoleta. I was under wowed by the exhibition both permanent and visiting.
OK museum. Free entrance. Art selection is pretty nice. Some pieces by famous artists like Goya. Good for a rainy afternoon.

Great free attraction. It is one of the museums that is work visiting on your way from Recoleta Cemetery. If you are short of time, just skip through the highlights of the museum that are marked on the visitor guide.

Modern art, Latin style.. A well laid out museum of South American modern art. As our tastes run more to traditional art, it was more of a curiosity; but if you like the modern art era, you'll enjoy this.

Focus on other museums. With MALBA, the Decorative Arts, and the Lacroze, Buenos Aires does not lack for compelling museums. The MNBA is not worth your time. It is free but that does not make it worthy. It may have some name painters but their examples here are dark and uninviting. I like to stroll through a museum and stop at those paintings that catch my fancy. Here it was all stroll and little stopping.

Very nice museum, beaufiful paintings, sculptures and pictures.. This museum contains a beautiful collection of very valuable paintings and sculptures from Europe and Argentina. The atmosphere is very quiet and there is a lot of free space for everybody who want to observe the paintings and the sculptures. The last room was dedicated to the old pictures of Buenos Aires. My husband and me liked very much the painting made by Charles Chaplin. There is no fee to be paid for the entry to the museum and it is highly recommended.

Beautiful Museum. This is a lovely museum with some high quality art pieces. It is small compared to many museums in cities within the United States but a fine place to visit for an hour or two. MALBA is more unique. MNBA is more classical.

it's free and has big name artists. The only reason I went there was because it was raining and my horseback riding trip was cancelled. I've been to museums all over the world and this was average at best. It felt like the budget was an issue and they were just open to be open. They did have paintings from top name artists and I did enjoy it at times. I then took the stairs from level 1 to 3; couldn't stop at 2 since it was closed. Level III appeared to be a bunch of crap in the attic. Anyway, if its raining and nothing to do in BA; its free and something to do for an hour or so.

A glimpse of local art. Located within the Palermo park, hosts permanent collections of Argentine and Latin American painters and some expressions of European authors, including some Rodin sculptures. Offers guided tours, audio guides in different languages or stroll by yourself in 2-3 hours

Special for art lovers only.... MNBA is a pearl for latin America, but unfortunately, can't be compared to north american or european museums. So, if you do not like art, skip it. If you do, you'll love it! It has a very special and enchanting collection. Positive points: near the plazas and many cafes and it's free!

Great collection of paintings. The Fine Arts museum is a short ten minute walk from Recoleta Cemetary. It is free, and houses a nice collection of European paintings from the renaissance to the Impressionists. The Degas drawings are particularly fine, there are some nice Toulouse-Lautrecs and a roomful of Rodin sculptures. The last three rooms are dedicated to Argentinian artists, some of which drew on local culture and peoples most interestingly. Well worth a visit.

Some good pieces, but not up to World standards. It is worth the visit, but even though you'll find a few nice pieces of art, for the most part this museum can't compete with the great museums of the world.

Nice free museum. The art museum had some paintings by famous painters like Toulouse-Latrec, Monet, Manet, Gauguin and more. It was free which surprised me. It is a small museum and I recommend about an hour to see it all. Unless you're the type you parks yourself in front of a painting and stares for hours. Then you'd need more time.
Go!. Spent a hour and a half going through the three Impressionist rooms, twice. Wow, and it's free. No sane reason not to go.

museum visit. nice museum - FREE - do not expect more than 2 or 3 painting by major renowned european artist like Van Gogh, El Greco, Renoir, Rubens, etc.....but at least you get to see the one or two painting from each of these famous painters. Well frequented by locals and tourists. Say about 8mins away from Recoleta cemetery and 3 from the "Open Flower"
Not to be missed. Do not miss this museum. It has a magnificent collection of paintings and sculptures, and it's not so large that it's overwhelming. A real treasure.

Really Nice Collection. For art lovers as myself, it is a must-go. It is free and they have incredible pieces from well-known artists. I loved the Degas, it's nice if you want to spend some hours away from the sun.

Nice. This is the national fine art museum. It has works by well known artists including Rembrandt, Degas, Renoir, Manet, Monet, Rubens, etc. It is a smaller collection, but nicely organized by genre, and not very crowded on the day we visited. Guide books are available for purchase. A nice way to spend a few hous

A small but nice collection. This is a very nice relatively small collection compared to the great museums of the world. But it is a representative collection nicely exhibited. They do have an English map, but no English signage except in the older European room.

Good, but glad it is free. The museum is free and it has a few works by famous artists (Manet, Monet, degas), but nothing extensive. It was good for us in that it was raining at the time, so we escaped the rain to look here. It felt like there was an extremely large number of works by "anonymous" which I have never seen in other art museums round the world. Good for an hour, but I wouldn't put it on my must see in buenos aires if I am crunched for time,

Impressive collection. Great way to spend a rainy afternoon in Buenos Aires. Admission is free. Can see the entire collection in about 2 hours. Lovely Argentinian art collection and large Degas and Rodin collections and found a new favorite to add to my list, William-Adolphe,Bouguereau. Museum is open every day except Monday

Mediocre but free. We stopped in because it seemed like a worthwhile visit. A large portion of the exhibits were closed while we were there and the "notable works" weren't extraordinary. Some nice Argentinian artwork but nothing that took my breathe away. I'd suggest stopping in only if you are killing time or ducking out of a rain shower.
Great collection! Must see art.... Very impressed at the permanent collection, lots to look at and admire... Thank god for two private donations that make up almost half the museum...

Extrordinary Surprises Abound. What's not to like about a collection that includes works by Manet, Monet, Sisley, Pissarro, Van Gogh, Toulouse Lautrec and more. Then there are the sculptures and some excellent work by local, Spanish and Italian artists. What is really interesting is that a lot of these are works that are a little unusual, Monet's trains and boats rather than hay stacks and water lilies, Lautrec's soldiers and a pastel portrait of a woman - interesting.I loved this place. It's not big but I don't want to be overpowered by quantity—quality abounds.This gallery opens at 12.30 during the week. Stroll from here to the Museo Nacional de Arte Decorativo which opens at 2pm.

Fantastic Museo. Had a visit to this wonderful Museo. Many items of world famous artists. Sculptures as well as paintings. They were all displayed beautifully and photos are allowed without using a flash. Even if you are not an art lover or appreciator, you should be impressed by this superb collection. Free entry. Very close to the Recoleta Cemetery so very easy to combine the two.
Great free museum. Great (if not huge) collection, handy location in Recoleta, and it's free! Check out the exhibition space out the back - it has a completely different feel.
Great Art!. Free on certian days of the week (closed on Sundays). Smaller than the museums American folks may be used to, you can finish it in a couple hours. Definitely worth visiting.

One of a kind museum. This is an amazing place to see Argentine and European art in a relaxed setting. Paintings and drawings from Picasso, Rembrandt,Kohlwitz, and others, with no pressure to move on because of crowds.

It's okay if you're in the area. The museum is nice, with some lovely impressionist paintings and some Argentinian art. There isn't a whole lot to see so you can complete the tour in 30 minutes or so.
A lovely morning. We spent a fantastic rainy morning here and thoroughly enjoyed the visit. Some great works of art and a must see in BA

all the Argentine art off-limits. We are puzzled by some of the TA reports which we read (after going to the MNBA). They are right to say it's free (a plus), a bit hard to find, and that the supply of info - both printed and via the museo personnel - is rather scanty. They're also right that the Euro collection (mostly Hirsch collection, I think) is - especially by Latin American standards - good and varied: from Renaissance thru to C19, including Goya, Van Gogh, etc. Also the Rodin. And, right now, a special exhibition of some fairly awful (recent) pictures of the heroes of Latin American Independence, chiefly notable for the sheer quantity of multi-coloured oil paint piled onto the canvas. But when we visited (Sept. 2013) the whole Argentine art section, which is what we most wanted to see, was closed ('for renovation'); and, while the big placard out front of the museo made some upbeat ref. to improvement being undertaken by the state, etc.., the timetable there did not conform to what the rather gloomy guide told us (and we speak Spanish, so no misunderstanding seems likely), i.e., that the 'renovation' had been going on, and wd go on, for some time (years, I think). Yet some recent visitor claims to have seen the Argentine art section in the last few weeks . . At any rate, it's worth a visit for the Euro collection, but comparisons with the NY Met or London National Gallery are wildly flattering.

Nice museum. It’s a free museum with some nice paintings. However, most of them are of national painters. It’s a place to go and get to know better some local culture. When I came there, it had a Carravaggio Exposition and that was wonderful.

Awesome place to spend the afternoon. I must say I am not a museum person but happened to chance the place as were walking around Recoleta. Full of paintings and sculptures by the famous painters including Van Gogh, Renoir, Monet, Rodin, etc.. And the best part, its free! Simply awesom.

Enjoy its offerings!. A note on its location (as some foreign visitors complain that the museum is not easy to find): on 1473 Libertador Avenue, just opposite Plaza Francia (Francia Square). Floralis Generica is on the left handside of the entry to the museum. On the official website, the explanations of how to get to the museum are clear. Now for the treasures you can enjoy: Italian and Flemish renaissance collections to the Impressionist works by Manet, Gaugin, Renoir, Degas, Goya oils, Rembrandt, Monet, Vincent Van Gogh, Antonio Berni, Benito Quinquela Martín, Antonio Seguí, Rodin sculptures (including "The Kiss"). What else can you ask? Absolutely breathtaking!Sometimes temporarily expositions are available. However, the real treasure is the permanent collection.I agree with a previous reviewer that reviewing art is highly subjective. However, the quality of the works in the museum is undeniable. Excellent to have a first-hand appreciation of some Art masters. Should be included in the “must see” list. Spacious, with well laid out halls and a modern looking rear area.Guided tours: information on the official website.I would definitely recommend it. Superb!Free. The timing hours are not that convenient. The museum should revise this. Interesting website about the museum: http://www.argentinavirtual.educ.ar/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=103&Itemid=111 Enjoy its offerings!
Surprisingly good. Good range of European and Argentinian art. Lovely building that is deceptively bigger than first appears.

Wonderful building and great variety of pieces. I always get mesmerized when I get into this museum. It has a feeling of other days, and a great disposition of pieces throughout the building. Very close to MALBA so you can plan both visits on a same day...

art lovers take a walk here". this museum has a nice environment is pettite compared to other big ones in other countries so its a friendly walk and do not forget to kiss Rodin before you leave you will find "El Beso" from Rodin, sweet,sad, a love paradox...visit this museum while doing Recoleta area along with cementery for those who like it....enjoy!

Ho hum . . .. I didn't find this museum all that interesting. A collection of European art -- but nothing you can't see in many other museums. The Latin American art was also not all that interesting -- up through around the late 1800s. It was fine, but I don't think this is a must-see (MALBA and Museo de Artes Plasticas de Sorvini fall into that category, for me).

Outstanding collection well worth a visit. While strolling through Recoleta, I happened upon the Museo Nacional de Bellas Artes. As someone else here mentioned, it's not all that easy to find and is kind of tucked away. I actually ended up at the University Law School building, an imposing Greco-Roman edifice nearby, thinking it was the museum. After finally getting my bearings, I was pressed for time and thought I would just take a brief walk through. Wow, what a mistake. As one who majored in Art History, I was blown away by the quality of the work housed in this museum. A room full of Goya oils was absolutely breathtaking. The quality of the works, from the Italian and Flemish renaissance collections to the Impressionist works by Manet, Gaugin, Renoir, Degas, etc was unsurpassed and worthy of an entire day of appreciation. There were so many important pieces that I had studied and to see them firsthand was inspiring. I would have never thought this was a "must see" museum, but I would definitely recommend it now and urge anyone travelling to Buenos Aires to stop and experience its offerings.
A smaller version of a good European museum.. Interesting permanent collection. Probably good to go when there is an exhibition - they were setting up for Caravaggio when we went.
Beautiful Museum. The art collection of Alfredo and Lisa Hirsch, is mostly Italian art from the renaissance period and alone is worth the visit.

Easily visited in one morning of afternoon. The collection here is not large, but of generally high quality. You will encounter some familiar artists, but also discover a few ones you may never have heard of before,

Excellent. Nevertheless its a public museum its amazing.If you are latinamerican as me you will know what we mean when we say for a museum that it is 'public'. This means mosty: bad administration, horrible execution and employees in bad mood and apatic.In spite of those (which are true here, will notice some if you observe) the museum is great.It's completly comparable to main museums in the world such as Prado, Louvre, Altes (Berlin), Old Masters Gallery (Dresden). Only by its collection, not by its services.Very recomendable.

Decent. This is a decent museum. Probably more of a 3.5. It is free which is great. If it wasn't, I'd give it a three. It actually can be hard to find the entrance. If you are on the side near the University of Buenos Aires, you need to walk all the way around to the other side. I felt Bellas Artes is worth coming to if you are pairing it with something else...like going to MALBA down the street (about a 20 minute walk) which is a better museum from my perspective.

Interesting collection, appalling visitor experience. I don't get the opportunity to experience international art very often so was looking forward to the Rembrandts, Monet, Corot and Manet . the art didn't disappoint me. The Argentinian collection was very interesting. My main issue was the frustration with the museum itself. There were no maps, visitor guides or guided tours. We thought we might've come through a back entrance as no signage or assistance from the staff we asked. The only time we got any response from the staff was when my husband leaned to close to an artwork. I still recommend going but hope others experience isn't as frustrating and confusing.

Excellent. Reviews of art are always going to be highly subjective based on your tastes. If you are looking for a museum full of Argentinian artists, this is not the place to visit, but there are plenty of others in the city. This museum, while not covering my favorite period of history, is nevertheless excellent, especially if you are fond of 18-19 century European art. We've been twice already and may go back before we leave BA (the fact that it is free factor in, but I think it has more than Malba, even though Malba covers some of my favorite periods somewhat).It has work beginning at about 16th C forward. It is very well laid out to take you through their collection. They have some amazing pieces that I just sit and stare at for while. My one complaint, which is the reason for 4 stars rather than 5, is that it is poorly lit in some areas, making it hard to fully appreciate certain works.
incredible artwork. Free - by donation. Art work from 16th Century and more recent. Has a Rembrant painting. Has much more than I expected.

A mini Met. A fantastic, little museum in Recoleta district of Buenos Aires. What we liked the most was how the art work was arranged. Religious artifacts (that we personally do not care about) along with El Greco and other works of fantastic art. They have at least a few works of every master: from Rembrandt (given that it was attributed to him) to Van Gogh. Room after room on the first floor awaited surprise after surprise. We loved our almost 2 hours in this small museum. Upstairs was a photographic exhibit which honestly we did not care about and the Botero exhibit was fine too. But the real treasure is their permanent collection and how they exhibit it. Also, the entrance is free. They open at 12:30 PM. Yes, it is Argentina after all. And they remain open till 8 PM.
Great art, intelligently presented. My wife and I loved this art museum. They have a wonderful collection, impressively presented. So much to see!

A good collection. This was actually a surprise for us. We went to the Museum but did not imagine that the collection was so good. The French impressionists are well represented and the exhibition of Botero's drawings was very interesting.

Not worth the effort. Yes, it's free admissions, but the museum is small, mostly non-native artwork (like Monet, Gaugain, etc), and half the museum was under construction. Experience Argentinian culture and history elsewhere. This museum is not worth the effort with all you can experience in town.
Disappointing. Skip this museum. For a city that loves art and design, I expected a better national musuem. The selection of Argentine art was tiny, and the building itself is wreck.

Excelent, check their site for guided tours. This is a great place for culture... not only do you have free guided tours, but also free classes with a wide selection of topics (spanish only). Go the their website and see their expositions.
After your finished, its a short walk from the Recoleta.

The best museum in BA. Beautiful with many classical paintings from all over the world. The entrance was free, and there were even guided tours explaining many of the paintings. There was a special display that month featuring el greco. A must see in BA.

Nice collection, free admission. This collection has works from many famous artists (both European and Argentine), but I agree with other reviews that the organization and presentation could be improved upon. I would recommend getting a guide (which we did not) if you do not read Spanish since none of the posted information is in any other language.

Good collection but poorly presented. The Museo (really an art gallery) has some excellent works by all the main European and local artists and is worth a half day visit. Enjoyment was marred by the poor presentation. Many of the labels were so badly prepared and lit that they were simply unreadable and there appeared to be no rhyme or reason to the layout of the works.

Nice surprises. I had a good time visiting this museum. It was smaller than I thought it would (and there was one floor completely closed due to a strike of the employees I think) but there was some really nice pieces. I've been very impressed by Goya's paintings and Rodin's marbles.
A must visit. The museum was walking distance to my hotel, and it had some great art pieces. I'm lucky because the week I was visiting they had a paper exhibition that I took advantage of.
Impressive venue. The tour of this exquisite building was outstanding. We had an excellent tour guide who spoke English well and even sang some opera for us demonstrating the acoustics in the hall.
Definitely worth visiting. This gallery is definitely worth a visit. Friendly vibe and a well organised space - all the rooms are very brightly coloured which creates a really decent environment.

Disappointed. Donde Esta Caravaggio?. Really disappointed that Caravaggio was not available as shown in front of the museum and several other permanent collections that were listed in my guidebook weren't available as well. Oh well, admission was free. And darn it, non-flash photography was not allowed and the gift shop was closed on a Saturday. Yep, disappointed big time.

Excellent gallery and beautifully laid out.. This is one of the best galleries - it is simple, with a modern layout, easy to stroll around and with excellent masterpieces... I was thrilled to find several Rodin's sculptures - well done !
Give it a try though... Feel a little mean with my rating here, but had been to MALBA first, and just enjoyed it so much more than MNBA..

Worth it for classic art lovers, check for rotating modern art exhibits. First of all I love classic art museums so here judge my review from there: I quite like MNBA, I've been twice and each time passed a great hour or so wandering their classics section. It's free so really I don't why you wouldn't at least give it a shot. The place is very big compared other national art museums, (I love the Smithsonian Art Galleries), but it is worth it for those who enjoy art. They also have rotating exhibits, the first time I went it was a super modern exhibit so if you prefer modern art don't write off MNBA right away. Love the drama of the building as well and for anyone staying in the Recoleta area it is a quick hop over.

Great collection. Popped in here to have a look at some Argentinian art and was very surprised at the amount of European art by some of the greats (including a lot of statues and paintings by Degas). Well worth a visit although at the time of our visit the top floor was closed, missing out the Caravaggio collection which hadn't been opened yet.
Very traditional. I'm not in a position to say whether the pieces in the museum are not worth the time, but the museum in itself is a very traditional museum and just seemed "boring" to me.

Worth a visit. We found most of the museums in this area opened at noon or later so we walked here after visiting the cemetery. We enjoyed the size of the collection, not too many rooms to be overwhelming but a variety of European artists were represented here. It was free as well. Another musuem is a few blocks away so it would be easy to visit both in an afternoon.

Good for a rainy day, but otherwise non essential. It was nice to see some examples of South American art.It was very big, as impressive, and didn't have the facilities of London galleries.However...entrance was free.

Great collection for quick visit. This museum has many lovely pieces, including a Van Gogh, a Rembrant and (to my delight) two Matisse originals! We rented the audio tour which was not worth the money.The collection is impressive but relatively small so art enthusiasts will be able to study pieces at length while art dabblers will find this just the right size.

Great works of art inside, and it's FREE!. I was amazed at all the great works of art inside -- Picasso, Rodin, Monet, Goya, etc. For some reason, I didn't expect to see such a great collection. Perhaps the exterior of the building seemed too modest looking. If you're an art lover, GO!
Wonderful Surprise. Really enjoyed the exhibits. They had a lot of art from well known artists and masters. A very well maintained museum.
Great Museum. Well worth a visit to this museum. It is free and has great exhibits. Cannot believe how close you can get to the paintings - very different from European museums.
Fine artworks. This museum has many beautiful works of wonder. You can spend hours inside. It's worth a little time separating from their trip to buenos aires for this museum.

Not worth your time. The museum is not up to standard with most other fine art museums we have visited around the world. A large section is simple sketch art, certainly not what you would expect in a fine art museum. Most of the museum staff are male and look at women in a terrible non respectable way. I do not recommend you visit this museum.

Amongst the best I've seen. Despite the fact the upper floor of modern art was closed I still judge this to be amongst the best art museums I've ever seen (and I've seen a lot!) I recognised four or five of the paintings in one room as the pictures on New Zealand's Christmas stamps. Obviously someone did a bulk deal at some stage. But they are fantastic. The Rodin scultures (including "The Kiss") were superb and I simply could not believe the number of wonderful paintings gathered together in one place. The displays are in a logical order although at times the tape I was litening to seemed to be referring to rooms that seem to have changed. When you come out of the museum if you turn left and go over the road on your right it's a short walk to the Recoleta Cemetary. I spent most of the day on these two sites alone.

A real gem. This art gallery near the Recoleta Cemetery is a beautiful little art museum with representative artwork fro around the world. It is extremely well presented and can be visited in a reasonable manor in about an hour, if you are rushed. Otherwise stay and enjoy.As far as I can tell it is a free exhibit set in a beautiful park setting.

Beautiful collection of Renaissance and other art. The art was great but the rooms were a little dark because they had to protect the paintings. The building was beautiful and near enough to the hotel so that one could walk there.
Great collection. Hot beyond belief. There was one room with adequate climatization. I can't believe that they keep their treasures under these conditions.

Amazing collection, great building in perfect location. When you are around Recoleta park, don't miss this museum. It's small enough not to get tired inside it but rich in art, you would never have imagined that this museum could hold these high quality collections. The guides are also super professional. There's a little bar at the end of one of the rooms, with comfy chairs and a perfect view. And it's free!

A Pleasant Surprise. Argentine art was not open when I visited, but the European collection was of surprisingly high quality. Obviously rich Argentinians enjoyed their visits to Paris a century ago, and purchased fine works of art to take home--Manet, Monet, Renoir, Degas, Toulouse-Latrec, etc.

FINE ARTS ON STRIKE. we the people may not see the fine arts on display because they the keepers are short on cash and that is called culture. Museum was closed and held hostage by underpaid minions of the city government, no posted notice - just a friendly GET LOST

Interesting range of exhibits. Wide range of South American and European paintings. The gallery was laid out well with plenty of space to move around on a busy Sunday afternoon. The Cafeteria was OK and gave us the opportunity to rest our feet.

An interesting museum. that has some magnificent paintings of European masters as well as Argentinian artists. The location of the building is not too far away from MALBA, about 1/2 hours walk through a nice neighborhood

Historical art. This museum is nice for people who want to learn about history while observing art. I tend to like more abstract art that allows me to make my own story. This museum had a lot of war themed art that would also allow you to imagine a scenario, just not one that interest me. I love art and I love history, but it was too focused on the combination of both for my taste. Glad I visited once but likely wont go again. The museum is free and has no air conditioning.

More than just Argentine artists. For art lover, this museum is a must. We were there in summer and it was hot. Like many places in BA, there is no air conditioning. For a small fee there is a wonderful audio tour of the museum and their amazing collection. During our visit there was a special exhibit of Latrec and Picasso. The permanent collection at the museum is impressive and we are members of the Art Institute of Chicago. There is also a small, but lovely gift shop with the most gracious and helpful salesman. In fact, all of the staff were wonderful.

Good selection of fine art. This museum has a mixed but interesting collection of impressionist, Argentine and other painters. Thereisa spectacular 16th century Flemish tapestry and a very fine Rembrandt. The museum is free and worth a visit

Beautifully presented. The actual art pieces are lovely if you like 17th century art. The best thing about the museum is every room is a different colour. It's a pretty ballsy move to put 17th century art in an orange room, but it works!
great art. this is a wonderful FREE opportunity. the art collection is broad, and includes a lot of my favorite impressionists. it is well lit and well displayed. a joy.

Beautiful and free. We visited this museum when the rain drove us out of Recoleta cemetery, and we're glad we did. The collection of mostly Latin American artists was beautiful and interesting, my favorite was the elaborate Spanish combs. It's small, and worth the visit.

Beautiful old museum, with a modest but nice collection. I love older art museums, and this place fits the bill perfectly. Its not terribly big, but has enough to keep you occupied for at least a few hours.
Good collection of classical European and Argentinian artists. Enjoyed the layout and presentation of this museum. Some excellent works by Rodin as well as paintings in the impressionist school.

Dim and dinky. The biggest plus point about this place is that admission is free. Even so, if you have been to any of the major art museums in Europe or NYC, do not bother with this unless you have time to kill. The rooms are poorly lit and ventilated (especially in summer), and do not do justice to the handful of masters that are in display. It's possible I visited at a bad time, when they were preparing for some temporary exhibitions upstairs - but that is pure speculation on my part, since there was no information available.

Intimate and manageable. It's no whopper, but the permanent exhibition here has some great works on show by some great masters - ones that have clearly slipped through the fingers of bigger European galleries somehow. Some great stuff is easily missed - I nearly strolled past all the Goyas!

Great setting and big diverse collection of art.. We really enjoyed this museum. We were amazed with the diversity and depth of the collection. Don,t miss it. Go to the park area behind and eat at the outside restaurant across the street from the chrome flower statue.
World Class Art Museum. Quite a large selection of sculptures and paintings dating to the renaissance. Many historical S.A. paintings.
Great Renaissance and early modern art. Exhibits are well organized and very pleasant - especially liked the Francesco Podesti. Bonus was the Art of Motorcycles, special exhibit.

Great gallery. A beautiful gallery with fantastic exhibits . It matches many european galleries and museums very well. Check out its great collection of works by Rodin. Unfortunately the first floor was closed so some exhibits were not on show, particularly, expressionists and modernists.

Wonderful Collection. Great way to spend an afternoon to see some amazing works of art. I had allot of time in BsAs and this was definitely worth taking in although it had never been recommended by locals. Good place to get out of the heat or out of the way.

European Art from 1500-1875. This is a comprehensive collection of artwork from Europe. Pieces include Van Gogh, Picasso, and Rembrandt. The works are stunning and the curator has done a terrific job with placement and lighting.

it's free, but not well-kept.. Giving it 4/5 mostly because it's a free attraction in a great location, and usually the exhibit in the very back is well-curated. The works could use some updated signage and the building needs some maintenance, especially improved air circulation and lighting. But it's across the street from the fair in Recoleta and small enough to stroll around to see the whole collection within an hour.

Well worth it, especially since it's free.... This museum has fine and varied art, well laid out, in nice spaces. No signage in English would be the only limitation--but since we US folks don't offer signage in Spanish this is not a complaint.It's walking distance for Ricoleto Cemetary, which many tourists visit, and makes a nice add-on if you have the time. No admission charge. Bags must be checked.

Nice Museum, Good Collection. I liked that it was free that day. It is a good collection, would have been much better had the upper floors also been open to the public. Definitely belongs on a "should see" list.
Interesting free museum. A collection of pre modern paintings with many old masters. Loved the bold colors on the walls that served as background for the pictures.

Good Collection. Great collection of art and it's a fairly nice walk on Av. de Libertador to see other sights. It's also free! Carravagio exhibition was a bonus, and the Medusa was highly guarded to say the least.

OK collection, nice space. Spacious and well laid out halls, but the collection is just OK for anyone who has been to many art museums. Part of the issue was that I went late in the day and the special exhibition (I think it was Caravaggio spelling?) was closed. However, it is free and worth a visit if you are in the area. You can stroll through the halls in under an hour.

Take the time to visit the Museo Nacional de Bellas Artes. The collection of art in this museum is quite remarkable. The guides are friendly, knowledgeable and helpful. Attend during the week and you might be lucky enough to enjoy a historical overview from an art perspective while it is being presented to visiting schoolchildren.

Good place to spend a few hours. I spent a few hours at the museum gawking at the art on display, some pieces by well known artists like Renoir, Gaugin, Goya, etc. Best of all, its free. We wanted to view the temporary Carravagio exhibition but it wasn't open to the public yet when we were there, pity!Don't bother with the audio guides, they do little apart from introducing each room and contain hardly any information on individual paintings, and are overpriced at 40 pesos.
Just about worth a visit as it is a free attraction,. A varied collection but no English interpretation of the works on display. We arrived late in the day and the rooms were very hot.

Classic Museum. This is a great museum, nice works by Argentinian and foreign artists, but not a must go if you are short on time. Nothing special for those who have been to the world's great museums.

Where are the Argentine artists?. We went to see the Caragaggio exhibit, such as it was. A very small presentation. The Museum is dominated by European artists -- and the collection is thin at best. I would skip this if I were to plan my day over. As I think about it now, why would I go to see European paintings in South America?
Beautiful Building and Exhibition. Check this place out and stop for a meal or a coffee across the way. Recommended. World class exhibitions and easy to reach.
Fine art. The museam is not to large to be overwhelming yet there is a great collection and many exibits to enjoy. We were fortunate enough to see the visiting El Greco paintings

Lesser known works of several masters. The museum is well laid out, the rear area is very modern looking. There are several works from the masters, though the pieces are probably unknown to someone who is not an art expert. Renoir, Picasso, Degas, Monet, Manet to name a quick few - all have pieces here. My favorite part was the war paintings of Candido Lopez because I had never seen anything like it. Best of all, its free.

Wonderful Free Art Collection. Outstanding art collection with depth in impressionism. It's a free "must see" attraction. Don't miss the outdoor sculptures and the famous metal flower on the block behind the museum.
Great Museum. Nice museum very open and with excellent presentation of artworks. Side restaurant is also nice Did give reduce fees for seniors
Classic art. This is a good museum, but isn't super unique to Buenos Aires since most of the art is classic European. If you want a more unique experience I recommend the MALBA museum.
Boring museum. For all the must- see suggestions for this museum, it was pretty dull compared to museums similar in size and scope in other international cities.

Best museum in Argentina. This is the best and oldest museum in Buenos Aires. It may not be the best for niche art or latin american modern art, but besides that, it is for sure the best museum in the country.
Great!. I am not an art expert, but I would imagine that this museum rivals the best museums in the world judging by the quantity and beauty of each piece of art work!

Name is misleading - the original is now a shopping mall. This has some nice art but it is small and the name is misleading - it is in a very modern building that is connected to the Modern Design Museum. And it is really small - but bus 67 stops there. The original is the Americanos Mall - not far from the Obelisk.

Surprise!!. This is a really great museum with everything from Rodin to great contemporary art and along with the Recoleta cultural Center well worth a visit even if you have already gone to the superb MALBA
Very interesting. Great pieces of many famous artist, nice rodin collection. I went to see the caravaggio expo, and found their own collection even more amazing.
Beautiful. I really liked my visit in this museum. Lots of beautiful art and the admittance was free. Also close to the Flora Generalis sculpture, so great location to visit.
Fantastic free museum. Unusual Impressionist and post impressionist masters up close and personal! The Caravaggio show was also spectacular. Go for the Medusa alone!

Must visit!. Great collection of masterpieces of many well known artists.
They have some problems with placing and it's not so easy to see well some paintings, however collection is very good and it's worth visiting.
Louvre and d 'Orsay In Miniature. Great collection of art works from a broad diiversity of periods. Especially fine assortment of Impressionists.

Beautiful and free. We saw many famous European artists,
like van Rembrant van Rijn, etc.
Realy worth the visit and after walk across to the
famous cemetary

Bellas Artes Amazing. We enjoyed visiting the Museo Nacional de Bellas Artes and loved that it's one of Buenos Aires' free attractions. Aside from being a little cold because of the rain, we were captivated by the art.
Nice exposition. Classic is always classic, enjoyable collection, do not miss it, especially interesting mini portrets.
RATING RATING RATING. A really nice place to visit and we had a great day just touring around and checking out the scenery.

would be great if it was open regularly!. we tried 3 times to visit only to be given different excuse why it wasn't open that day despite other signs saying it was! Pretty annoying for visitors who've often travelled thousands of kilometers to see all that BA has to offer!
Nice collection and free. A small museum with European and Argentine art all on one level, very easy to see in two hours. And best of all, it is free!

Closed floors. My wife and I were excited by the prospect of seeing 2000+ year-old art and artifacts, but when we got there we were told that the floors were closed for construction. That was too bad for us, but the museum had some interesting pieces and a Caravaggio exhibition that was worth seeing especially because it was free.

Not impressive. Most of the art was second tier. If you have visited a lot of art museums, you will be disappointed with the quality of most of the works. However, the artwork was beautifully displayed in gorgeous frames, and the layout was easy to navigate.

Good museum. Good collection of art in Recoleta - and its free. good to combo with a trip to the cemetary as it is only a couple blocks away. Behind the museum is the giant silver flower to check out.

Great for those who love art!. This was one of the highlights of my trip with friends to Argentina. The architecture of the building sets up the rich culture and historical environment within its doors, and the collection of art it houses is truly amazing. To see prints by Goya was probably one thing that I've always wanted to see in real life, and the rest of the permanent exhibition is not anywhere shadowed by these masterpieces. The contemporary art section around the back was also very exciting and innovative. This museum captures the past and the present art scene in the heart of Argentina's Capitol.
small museum. I think the best part of visiting this museum was building itself, it is so pretty. The exposition was interesting but on a smaller side.
disappointed. 2 of their 3 floors were being renovated and we didn't really see that much on the first floor. it's a shame.

Splendid collection. I was amazed and at the same time surprised with the museum's own collection. It ranges from famous painters and sculptors as renoir and rodin to local artists. The museum is very organized and stylized in a d'Orsay fashion, with colourful walls and rooms with a specific genre. I was very surprised to find out that it costs absolutely nothing to visit the museum. In my honest opinion, this museum is a must and covers most of the art periods, unlike Malba, which is dedicated to modern art.
Very Nice Collection of Argentinian Art. Nice museum with good collection of Argentinian artists. Have a guide take you to explain the collection - helps give the right perspective.

Small museum. Not a bad collection, but small. If you have and hour and a half to spare, it's worth it, especially because it's free. Open in the afternoon. Mostly Europeans in the collection (Degas, Monet, Rodin, etc.).

Some old friends. Being a Van Gogh fan, it was wonderful to visit and see yet another of his works! This gallery is chock full of some wonderful pieces from well known international artists (eg Rembrandt, Renoir) but also artists from South American that I had never encountered before in my travels. A great gallery to visit.
Wonderful museum, decent collection.. This museum is in a fine location and its a must visit between a walk by the Floralis Genérica and Recoletta.
Very cool. A must-see... exhibits are changing all the time, of course. open surprisingly late during the week (until 6).

Small museum with some well known French masters. Fine arts museum in BA. This is a smaller museum than what one finds in other big cities. They have a good collection of local and European artists such as Monet, Degas, Corot. There were some nice sculptures as well. We could not see the Argentine art section because there was a delay in opening it. Entry is free.

It's worth but ...... First of all: When I go to a museum , i like taking fotos, without flash, of course. Here is forbiden.(very old concept, or to sell more at the shop?)Several descriptions are wrong, like the date of the conquest of Constantinople by othomans.Several masterpieces are badly lit, like the japanese miniatures, or with blinding spotlights like the painting is just behind the desk of the reception.The shop of the museum is poor. You will find the same books are in an ordinary bookshop.It is great the entrance is free.The half of the museum is closed !!! ( the first floor) , it is open only the ground floor. It is a shame !!

Ensure you visit this free Museum. This National Museum is a must for a visitor to Buenos Aires. It offers a great selection of art dating back to 15th century.It is a beautiful building as well and I was surprised to see that photographs were allowed in some rooms.

gorgeous museum, very contemporary. We went on an opening night - free wine and champagne for all! Who knew? The art was bright and powerful - the lighting was of the work was art itself. A great eclectic collection, worth an hour or two.

Something for everyone. A great museum containing something for everyone. Free entry. The main halls contain exhibits dating from the middle ages through to modern day. Those massive tapestries/carpets hanging from the walls are amazing - just how did they make them? For those more familiar with art many of the artists will be familiar. But even we recognised both the style and the names of the likes of Manet, Monet, Rodin, Toulouse Lautrec, Vincent Van Gogh & Gauguin. In a large separate hall was a photographic exhibition depicting Buenos Aires life across the ages. Very interesting and it gave a great feel for times gone by. Check your coat - the museum was like a sauna it was so hot.

Extensive collection. This gallery is definitely worth visiting....with the assistance of some very generous benefactors the gallery has amassed a wonderful collection...from the magnificent Degas to the Spanish impressionists. Rodin sculptures scattered throughout ...and Greco to Rothko.This gallery makes for a wonderful few hours.

It is free. It is in Ave. Libertador one of the most beautiful ave. of the city. It is no so big, but very interestest. Just 4 blocks you can enjoy the Museo de Arte Decorativo and the Malba Coleccion Constantini.

everything is there. The world's largest collection of Argentine art is displayed in this huge golden-color stone building. Most of the 24 richly colored ground-floor galleries contain pre-20th century European art.

Cheap and excellent. Cheap films - only 12 pesos for students. A wide selection of independent films available. Careful with your selection, can be graphic. Classic films also shown.
One of the best museums in BA.

A gem. I spent a wonderful afternoon at this inspiring museum today and reccomend it without reservation to any traveller who loves art and beauty. Full to the brim with exquisite Rodin sculptures, French impressionists known and less familiar, Italian and South American artists, this is a must. A beautiful collection-well set out with the added and interesting challenge of translating the Spanish commentaries ( surely not too much to ask for any culture and art lover-get to know the country you are visiting!) you will not go wrong here. I am frankly amazed at some of the comments I have read-depressing to reawhile the flower of so much of all we revere is so easily discounted. Fellow reviewers, get a grip and visit, having spent an hour or so in the fantastic cemetery nearby.

great Museum. Great list of artists, don't know who cured or organized it but it takes you to a great historic ride of art thru time. a great experience.Pros.its FREE!!!Cons.Cant be cons on free stuff

A good artist list. This is a substantial collection. Monet, Toulouse Lautrec, Rodin, some good 14th century pieces - all great artists but not their greatest works. There is a salon of some very good Goyas that are worth a look. The Ming "collection" is poor
Best Museum In Buenos Aires. Amazing collection of paintings, from local artists and famous European artists alike. A must see for tourists and locals alike!

Learn Spanish first. The collection is interesting. There are some amazing pieces - but you won't learn anything about them unless you are fluent in Spanish as there is no audio guide. So its a nice way to kill a few hours browsing - but a little more focus on tourism would be appreciated.

Really worth a visit!. I was a bit sceptical as I've been to many arts museums but this was really good. The quality and variety of paintings were really good.The exhibition on show was really great too! It was called something visual - modern art. Normally I don't like modern art but this exhibition is great. If it's still on - definitely worth going.Also it's free!

Worth a visit. The museum has some very impressive pieces and I was very happy to see "Vahine no te mit" by Gaugain. They also seemed to have quite a number of paintings and sketches by Degas. The only minus I would give the museum is that the space provided for many of the European paintings was not afforded for the Argentinian and Spanish paintings. It felt rather cramped seeing them bunched together in places. Overall this a wonderful museum and how can you beat the price?

One of my favorites!. It was free when we went, I'm not sure if that is how it is always, or if we went on a special day, either way it's either super cheap or FREE, and you can't beat that! We went to several museums over three weeks in Buenos Aires and this was one of our favorites! They have a large and wonderful collection of art! The only thing I wish I would have done would have been to fork over the minimal fee to get the headset so I could learn more about the artwork, considering it was all in Spanish. Great art museum!
It's no worthed. Unless you are an artist . But the area is very pretty

Van Gogh on display. I came here with my camera and started snapping away when they kindly told me that I wasnt allowed to take pictures?? Maybe they wanted me to buy the museum book with the high resolution photographs?Anyway found 2 Van Gogh works and other fine paintings on display. My artistic side is not the most developed but I could still make out the beautiful from the not so nice.
One of the best museums in buenos aires. Always good things to see. Argentine art and international as well.
Free. This is a big museum but it is free and has cafes and a park nearby should you wish to chill out for a while before taking in more art.
It's worth taking the time to see. The Museo is small but filled with beautiful art. It's close to many other must see spots in BA so take the time a check it out

Old and new - Fantastic and free. Was really pleasantly surprised with this one. Having been to the equivalent in Santiago a few days prior, I expected something broadly similar but this was amazing. Really lovely pieces by Degas, Monet, Gauguin, and many others. From here you move into the 'contemporary' art section featuring optical illusion works and electrically powered gizmos from the 1920's to 70's. Light interference patterns, giant lenses etc were all here. If you like lava lamps, this is the kind of place you will enjoy. Two quick tips: you need a passport or photo Id to get the English audio guide- we missed out on account of this. And have a drink before you go in - there is no cafe inside and you must leave and reenter if you need a drink.
Lovely museum. We spent an hour viewing this museum,we liked it because it was spacious,had very good art exhibits and also it was free.

Bella artes. Easy walk to get there. Wonderful art inside. Headphone rental not neat entrance, even though you have to place purse in locker before you enter.... Then how do you pay for rental? Not very well planned! But overall, very nice museum.

not only this museum. Well I would say this is a must see but try also the museum of Decorative Arts !!!! you wonnt belive it very very interesting not only the building...............you get a taste of how a rich family the fine aspect of living was living...........just GREAT Plus they invite apart from the permanent collection also sessonals..a must SEEBy the way the food in the fine restaurant ist excellent

Nice Museum. This is a smaller museum that you can visit quickly or take your time to peruse. Various kinds of art, mostly paintings, and well located in the recoletta near the bus stop. Well worth the visit if you are spending a day in the barrio.

?Lost artists. Modern building with some great architectural features and art but one was left wondering if like other parts of Argentinian society there are lost generations of artists or if they are still coming to grips with a harsh political history

A nice stop, especially if you're into impressionism. This is a nice, small, free museum. I enjoyed walking around and getting an impression of what the Argentine Elite valued in fine art--most if not all of it comes from Europe. There is a copy of Rodin's Kiss there, and a good impressionist collection as well. Go walk among the statues in the parks surrounding the museum--those are even cooler.

A Fabulous Art Museum. I always visit this art museum when in BA. It has an extensive collection of Argentinean art, my favourite, Candido Lopez, plus good examples of French Impressionists. It also has excellent exhiditions.
Museum of Art in BA. With classic pieces, a few Rodin sculptures and a Renoir that is breathtaking...

A great afternoon- for free!. This museum reunites good European art displays from several centuries, which was quite a surprise. But it's Argentinian art display was also very charming! The best of all, for free!
Art and collections. Nice place close to downtown and Recoleta with a lot of masterpieces in the walls.

A great collection. As a museum director I always find it fascinating how other museums do things. In the case of this museum, the collection is exceptionally fine. I was actually amazed at the breadth and depth of the collection. It was presented in a very standard, professional museum way typical for an art museum. We, however, were less than impressed by the attention given to visitor services. We were not warmly welcomed, a guard barely nodded in our direction and made a directive about no photographs in the museum. There was no map of the museum so we already felt lost. We were finally pointed to the beginning point and once there discovered that many of the labels had the headphone sign that usually means an audio tour. My partner went looking for it, since all of the labels were in Spanish only and we wanted to know more about the collection. Instead of having an area set up in the lobby to handle this, he had to search through the museum until he finally found a "gift shop" area where he could rent them. It was cheap and it was well worth the hunt! The audio guide is well done for most of the galleries. However, at the end, they have made some changes to their exhibitions and have not updated the audio guide - so it was a bit confusing. Another thing we noted was that most of the secuity personnel hovered in dark corners, did not smile and in some cases were sleeping instead of engaging with the visitors (there were a number of school children there). All that being said, it was a fantastic museum with a fine collection of Masters from around the world.

Free museum filled with wonderful things. I came with low expectations and came away completely satisfied. I would recommend this museum to anyone. It holds some wonderful reproductions and original treasures. It is located near plaza francia and the recoleta cemetery so it makes for a wonderful grouping for a walk about type of tour.

Make time to view this gem. What a delightful exhibit. We were greeted warmly and directed to the commencement of this extensive body of work and it did not disappoint. The extent of this exhibit is vast and all works of a very high standard. The professionalism of presentation and the fact that it was all free added to the enjoyment of the museum. The Rodin sculptures were breathtaking nor did we expect to see a Van Gough so far from home, to name but a few delights of this museum. We stumbled upon the fact they had audio support which we paid to experience and glad we had. Our only initial disappointment was the minimal amount of South American art but sadly we discovered after the fact that it was all on the second level. Unfortunately we are not Spanish speakers and if there was any complaint of this museum is the fact that there is not enough information of what is on offer in languages other than Spanish.Great gift shop which was a nice little bonus.

Unexpectedly high-quality collection. MNBA is sometimes hard to get into (since it opens late and is closed on many public holidays) but once you're in, you'll be pleasantly surprised by the collection which includes Manet, El Greco, Goya and Rodin sculptures. The galleries are pleasant to stroll through and the collection is well laid-out.

The Art Museum of Argentina. Well worth a visit. Permanent collection has some paintings by classic European artists including some fine Rodin sculptures. Exhibits interesting works by Argentine artists. Some highly detailed depictions of the war with Paraguay that took place in the 19th century.

Nice, but I expected more. This is a good museum with some nice pieces of art, but I expected way more from a national museum of fine arts. Only visit if you love art or have time to spare because there are much better things to do in Buenos Aires.
it is okay. there is some construction going on and what they have is not so great. wait until they complete the work
An amazing art museum. Don't miss this! A wonderful selection of European and Argentinean art.

Awesome!!!. This museum is amazing! a great colection of art, with pieces of masters of classicism, surrealism, of Argentine art and many other styles. Renoir, Van Gogh, Rembrant, Manet, it's a great oportunity to see great painters in a very beautiful building. I recomend it!

Amazing - better than Paris and London. Wonderful few hours visiting this amazing museum. Definitely the highlight of 'things to do' in Buenos Aires. Obviously visiting art museums is a personal experience, but if you enjoy outstanding art, superbly presented, in a wonderful atmosphere, this is the museum to visit.

Feels like home. Not only the MNBA has a great permanent collection, but also has a quiet feeling that always makes me feels at ease. You can wander around going from Rodin to Rothko and always find something new (and for free!)

Great collection of Argentinian and European masters. Beautiful museum filled with many works by the great masters... Matisse, Cezanne, Rembrandt, Picasso, Degas, Van Gogh, Renoir, Monet, Toulouse-Lautrec.

A Gem with a Secret. We went in February (summer in Argentina) and it was quite warm. This museum has an outstanding collection of the great Argentinian artists. There is also a nice selection of Old World Masters and some European Impressionist paintings, especially Degas' paintings and drawings of ballerinas. Entry is free and well worth the visit. You can rent the audio program in the gift shop, but you have to provide a photo ID (i.e., driver's license) like in most museums. The museum does not have central air conditioning, so consider going early. The secret around this is that there is one large room that is to your immediate left upon entry that has air conditioning! So we would visit a wing and then return to the air conditioned wing to cool off, and repeat this episode several times, so we could take our time and really immerse ourselves in this wonderful art work.
Cultural Moment. Not far from Recoleta Cemetery, in the Museo you can admire works by Rubens, Monet, Renoir, Van Gogh, Picasso and by other graet masters. I love it and the best: It's free.

Surprise. This museum has an excellent collection of Old Master's art, quite a few of Degas' paintings and drawings, all of ballerina's, of course, and a small but excellent collection of religious art. It is free and well worth a visit. Note: if you want to have the audio program you have to go to the gift shop to rent and provide a photo ID (i.e., driver's license) for them to hold until you return the equipment. However, no one tells you this until you have stored your bags and purses (required, but free) requiring you to pull your bag out of storage. If you carry a wallet in your trousers you won't have the problem.

Fine Arts in Buenos Aires. A friend and I spent a couple of hours viewing the art at this museum in the Recoleta neighborhood of Buenos Aires. There is no admission charge for this museum that houses a number of Impressionist artists that are certainly worth your time. For those of us that have a limited attention span, this is just the right place to spend some quality time. The location is perfect to coordinate with a stop at the Recoleta Cemetary. Enjoy!
Very nice to visit. A very good museum. Very important paintings form local artists. Worth a visit. I think it's free

Well organised museo with many world class paintings on display. From the Argentinians, italian, French, Dutch and othes world famous painters like Goya, Rembrandt and many others, sculptures and many other things on display. This place hasa lot to offer. We were sorry to have to leave after only two hours on account of our 3 year old getting bored and acting up. Well worth the visit. And it' s all free. You can make a donation if You like, but it' s voluntary and nobody will ask.

Art and a lovely setting. In Recoleta, sandwiched by Figueroa Alcorta and Libertador Avenues, in the first parks of the Palermo area, it has an impressive collection of art and its surrounding areas are lovely. A few steps away from Recoleta Cemetery.

Satisfying. BA is rightfully proud of its more traditional art collection. This is a great place to visit on a hot or rainy day. The collection covers the centuries and cultures. I learned about Argentina as I viewed the collection. No cost.

Fairly large collection of impressive works of art. There are a few great pieces in here, particularly some Rodin sculptures, but most of the art here is just very good, and not great. I did not find any Diego Rivera or Frida Kahlo, which is disappointing in a prestigious Latin American museum. Still, it is a large building and worth a 2 hour visit.They will require you to check any backpack or large bag. We checked one bag without incident.
Great art but no air-conditioning. Large selection of great art. However, it was about 80F inside so I'm concerned about preserving the art.
Somewhat disappointing and very warm inside.. Some good if limited French art in the collection but the building is dark inside and the content in general is thin.
Surprising. The don't have the best pictures but they have one of every famous Impressionist artist besides the local ones.

Must-See Collections For Free. The museum houses classic painters and sculptures. We were surprised to find them there and in Buenos Aires. We loved this museum and it's free! Don't miss it if you love the classic artists.

Fantastic collection of Latin Art. I always go to the Museo Nacional de Bellas Artes when I'm in Buenos Aires. I can't get enough of the paintings and the history of Latin America. Of course you can go to the city for some shopping, but should never forget culture. The place is very well organized within its three floors ( second is closed 'till July 2012). It's collection of Argentinian painters is something not to be missed as well as its Gauguin, Renoir and other masters.One of my favorites is Ernesto de la Cárcov's painting called " Sin pan y sin trabajo". Its sad, strong and portraits despair, but its unique. Don't miss it.

Great collection. Great collection of fine art including some outstanding tapestries. Despite the size of the building, the collection is small enough to fully absorb without being overwhelmed. The museum can be rather warm during the heat of the day, so if you are there during the summer, you may want to visit in the morning. There is no fee to visit.
Great art collection. This museo is very good to visit, has a great art collection, and it's free!
Excellent place to visit. Full of stunning paintings, Monet, Manet, Toulouse-Letrec, Sisley, many many others. Also The Kiss by Rodin (unexpectedly_)

Outstanding collection. Really great collection - highlights include several memorable pieces by Rodan, Pissarro, Corot, Degas, and Van Gogh. The museum isn't too large and is easy to navigate. Definitely worth the time!

A must for Art lovers. There is no fee to visit the Museum. There is a desk in the lobby where you can buy the official guide of the MNBA for 30 pesos (about 7 dollars). They have a spanish and an English version of it. It is beautifully illustrated and it is a nice souvenir of your visit. They ask you to leave your bag at the door but I can guarantee you that I've had no problem whatsoever. I had money, cards, a camera in there and nothing went missing. The collection is astounding. Renoir, Rembrand,Corot,Modigliani, Léger,Rouault,El Greco,Degas, Pissaro,Gauguin,Fantin-Latour,Courbet.....There is also Argentinian art of the early 20 th century. On the second floor they have Argentinian and international photography and a sculpture terrace. A wonderful place to see if you are an art lover. And don't miss Plaza Francia across the street with it's beautiful trees and wonderful sculpture.

Nice selection of impressionists!. Totally worth the time and effort to see their museum. It had some nice works by Renoir, Degas, Rodin, Gauguin and many others. Very nice, free of charge. Worthy of 1-2 hours as it's close to the Recoleta Cemetery is located.

Don't bring a purse/bag. Upon entering the Bellas Artes, we were asked to check in our bags. I had a medium-sized purse and my husband's bag was not much bigger. In all my travels through 5 continents and many museums, I have NEVER been asked to leave my PURSE anywhere. In my opinion, this is equivalent to asking for a man's wallet! We thought this was unreasonable and left rather than risk losing any of our valuables. So, if you visit this museum, don't bring your purse/bag or ensure all your valuables can fit in your pockets. I don't know if they'd force you to check in your jacket too.
Must See!. You will be surprised by what art you will see. Check opening times.

Be Careful!. Currently the Museum is undergoing a renovation, which means no Air Conditioning and only a few of the art pieces are on display. Since it's free you can't really complain. The trip for us however ended up costing $60. When we entered the Museum we had to check our bags at the security desk, I made of mistake of leaving some of our bigger ($250 Pesos) in the bag. Our money didn't get stolen outright, it would've been better if it had been. The "security" desk swapped our cash (which was from the ATM) with fake currency! We tried to pay a cab fare with it immediately after the Museum and we were denied, we checked the currency with local businesses not really understanding the cab driver and they told us the same thing. With our limited spanish we really couldn't do much so we just chalked it up as a loss! ...In conclusion, visit the Museum but be careful about what you check at the security desk.

Great art! Good for museum lovers.. I thought the European art was great. Great masters' works, some if which I never knew existed ( not in books, nor do they seem to lend/ tour to other museums). Latin American art was great to. Some were great masters but we never heard of! So great and educational.Not all parts if the museum were air conditioned and the bathrooms could be nicer but otherwise good museum!

Very Relaxing - All Quality, no hype - An excellent Art experience in a great neighborhood. I am into art, but came to Buenos Aires to eat. Having been to Paris and Berlin for my last two big trips, I thought that I would let my normally busy art-mind rest here in BA. After a week of urban life, however, I was ready to get some art in and settle myself a bit. Taking a taxi here from Palermo took only a few minutes, about $5 USD. Entering the museum and starting with the galleries to the right, I was immediately impressed. Here you will see works by all of the usual European masters, but you have not seen these works, before. Also, the painting are hung very well in well design galleries. I spent two hours here, on a Sunday morning, and had the place largely to myself. It was an excellent experience!  Afterwards, I walked just a couple of blocks to the craft fair at Plaza San Martin de Tours, which I also enjoyed very much. Good quality crafts here and a good place to buy a gift or two. The park was filled with locals enjoy themselves, cafes nearby, street performers. Another block brought me to the cemetery, also good. Really a great little outing, before catching the 10 bus back to the zoo. All relaxed and sane, very nice. Enthusiastically, I recommend this museum!

See the second floor first!. I visited the Museo one afternoon with only a couple of hours to spare. I started off on the first floor and saw the impressionist European masters. My advice is, if you've been to Europe or the US and have seen Monet, Degas, Van Gogh before - move quickly upstairs to the work of the Argentinian masters. There are many wonderful landscape paintings and portraits from previous centuries, but the Modern art section of the museum is truly not to be missed. Even if you are not generally "in to" modern art, I felt that viewing the works gave me a sense of the political and social issues that are important in Argentina today. Huge, excellent, intriguing, works.

Impressive collection of artwork. Impressive collection of artwork from the Middle Ages up to the 20th century. And the admission was only a few pesos! Too bad there were only Spanish descriptions beside the paintings, so I could only enjoy the paintings but wasn't able to learn more in-depth about the artists.

Good museum.. I visited the National Art Fine Arts museum on my last day in Buenos Aires. It is located in Recoleta, literally within a (long) stone's throw of the cemetery. Entrance is free, although an audio guide is available at the book store in the center of the museum on the ground floor for 35 Argentine pesos.The collection is roughly divided into two sections: a collection of Western/European art on the ground floor spanning five Centuries and including many Old Masters such as Rembrandt (or his workshop), Matisse, van Gogh, Monet, Rodin, etc. All of these are covered on the audio guide. Highlights for me were the Rodin sculptures (personally donated by Rodin himself) and the Hirsch collection.I didn't fly 6,000 miles on a first trip to South America to just see European paintings, so I was happy to find the 2nd floor dedicated to Argentine and South American artists, including a whole room with pre-historic Columbian art. This was the highpoint of the experience for me as I was introduced to a whole group of artists previously unknown to myself. There seemed to be a bit of construction on the second floor as well, making the tour incomplete with several missing selections on the audio guide but this didn't detract from the overall experience.Definitely recommended for art fans.

Excellent Attraction. One of my favorite attractions in Buenos Aires. This museum contains hundreds of works of art including some from prominent artists such as Monet and Cezanne. I really enjoyed my time at Bellas Artes and would recommend it to anyone visiting BA. Not only is it free, it is conveniently located near a park and admission is free. What more could you ask for? Although you could spend all day there, even if you just have a few hours, it is still worth seeing.
Nice paintings. Wonderful localization and a lot of paintings from the masters. You can see Picasso, Monet and many others.Free admission.

Being a National Museum with not private collections I believe is the best!. We have to clarify that this is not a private collecion. Is part of our national budget.So I love this museum because with this limitation has the best paitings !

Rare Chance to view the19th & 20thC Argentine Masters. For art lovers, the Museo National des Bellas Artes in Buenos Aires houses a first rate collection. There are a surprising number of great impressionist works by Cezanne, Degas, Renoir, Monet and Gaugin among others, but works by these masters can been viewed in museums around the world. This is not to say that one should not also enjoy the European works on display at the MNBA, but the unique offering of this fine museum is the rare opportunity to see the work of great Argentine artists who are sparsely represented, if at all, in collections outside of Argentina. I was particularly impressed with the work of the late 19thC artists in gallery 105A, sala 33 on the Primer Piso. Take a good look at the three paintings by Angel Della Valle, La veulta del malón—an extraordinarily powerful painting representing the desire of the native Indians of South America to take back their culture from the Christianizing Europeans. Notice the fierce visage of the leader on his charging horse holding high a captured crucifix, while on his right, one of his warriors has a captured white woman and on his left a warrior carries what looks like a captured briefcase from their white oppressors. This is an absolutely wonderful, unforgettable painting which attempts, through art, to bear witness to the rage of the indigenous peoples of the New World in their struggle for survival. Della Valle’s other two paintings in this room are also inspired: the Gauchos a caballo c. 1900 with it suffused red composition and stark placement of men and horses is beautiful as is the El juego del pato, another scene of men and horses which Della Valle excels at depicting. While you are in sala 33, make sure to look carefully at the Eduardo Sivori paintings too, particularly the El despertar de la criada (Waking of the Maid). This is a masterpiece of light and shade. My wife particularly liked the Costurera, 1906, by José Antonio Terry which is also in sala 33.I would also suggest that you take a careful look too at the Bemberg Collection in sala 32 which contains the work of the Uruguayan painter, Pedro Figari. These are marvelous paintings from a true master. In addition, check out the Quiros gallery 105C, sala 35 for the Series “Los Gauchos” by Cesáreo Bernaldo De Quiros.You will come away from your experience of MNBA truly enriched with a real sense of the power, the beauty and wonder of Argentine painting at its best in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. This museum offers so much that more than one trip is justified.If you love painting, take this rare opportunity to see the work of masters little known outside of South America. I assure you, you’ll be rewarded.

A large impressive collection. Overview:This is a museum located in La Recoleta neighborhood that houses a number of fine pieces of art. It is a large collection that is open to the public. In October of 2008 the admission was free. This museum has several paintings from all over the world. Several paintings were from very well known artists. It takes a couple of hours to see the museum.Location:The museum is located in La Recoleta neighborhood within about a 10 minute walk from the cemetary. It is on the edge of the large park blocks where large green open recreational areas are located. Behind the museum to the side is a large pedestrian bridge over the highway and part of the university of BA.My Opinion:If you love or even just like art, it is well worth your 2 hours to see it. Leave a donation if possible.

Best Collection. This is a great choice for a general collection, and it was interesting to see not so famous works by famous and familiar artists. The best part is the Argentine collection on the second floor, so save some energy for that. We went in December and the air conditioning was iffy, very stuffy in many areas. There was no gallery map or list of events; there was no audio tour offered; and there was no gift shop. Admission is free, but they do need the donations.

Amazing!. I have visited some of the world's best museums, and this one, although smaller, has a wonderful collection...Lots of pieces by well known artists, and the museum is easy to navigate. You'll spend about 1-2 hours in the there...It was beautiful, and best of all is was free!!!! They have a wonderful collection of pieces by Degas...Gorgeous ballerina paintings...You can walk here from Recoleta...It's almost across the street...Don't miss this place!

Who Says The Best Things In Life Are Not Free. This is a fine,comprehensive art museum with a vast array of fine European paintings by artists like; Giovanni Da Milano,Titian,Jan C.Oostansen,Bartolomeus Bruyn,Rubens,Rembrandt,El Greco,Corot,Goya,Rafaelli,Monet,Sisley,Modigliani,and Picasso just to name a few. My favorite European works were Monet:'s ¨Bank of the Seine River and Sisley's Riverside..I also appreciated their splendid Argentine paintings by such Argentine painters as;Candido Lopez,Eduardo Sivori,Benito Quinqela Martin,Fray Butler,Emilio Pettoruti,Centurion,Alfredo Guttero,and Xul Solar just to mention a few.This delightful art museum is located very close to the Recolleta Cemetery. I spent two enriching days at this museum which is free of charge.P.S. My favorite Argentine paintings were;Centurion's Native Venus and Quinqela Martin's Riachuelo.
